I loved being a racing driver and driving racing cars. I am addicted to it, and it is all I know how to do. But I don’t do it anymore. I couldn’t even if I wanted to. I thought about what I should do now. A racing driver should have one or two backup plans for when he stops racing. I thought I had some, but when I tried to reach for them, they disappeared. 

How about being a commentator at the racetrack? There were many former Indy and Formula One drivers wanting to be commentators. Or maybe I could sell classic cars? That plan lasted all winter with phone calls, lunches, lawyers, and meetings with bankers. But it was a bad year for selling old Ferraris, so I decided to step back before I lost everything. 

Being an 'ex' anything is hard. How much do you want to hear about how I almost became the World Champion? Nobody wants to hear a story that ends with 'almost.' Even if I had been the champion, you would probably only want to hear the story for a few minutes before getting bored. Last year’s champion is last year. I don’t want sympathy, and I don’t get any. Why should I? I had a good career, made money, and saved enough. But I miss the excitement of getting into that powerful racing car. I miss the thrill of going from zero to one hundred and fifty miles an hour in 4.9 seconds. I even miss the danger of racing. 

I miss the bright and interesting people and the reporters who acted like what I said was important. Being famous, even a little, has its perks. Businessmen and politicians liked to tell their friends they knew me. Little boys would sneak under fences to get my autograph. And now that I don’t drive anymore, I have a lot of free time. Just last week, the phone rang twice. I have time in the morning and afternoon, and tomorrow looks free too. I looked up at the clear blue sky. There were no buzzards flying above. Maybe Arizona doesn’t have buzzards. But a couple of small brown birds in a cactus nearby were warning me to leave their nest alone. I never thought the desert had songbirds. I realized that a fake cowboy in designer boots still has a lot to learn.'

**Text: Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, residents walk through the city streets, and if you join them, you will likely hear different languages being spoken. People come to Vancouver for its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and good educational and job opportunities. Although some locals may complain about how quickly new buildings are being built, it is clear that the new residents and growing tourism have helped improve the city. In the past, locals called Vancouver 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Although this name is not used as much now, Vancouver is still a major gateway.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists like me are often not good at writing letters. Some say this is because we do not like to write for free, but I think it is more about how we try to make our writing very effective in our work. This focus on effect can make writing a letter feel less spontaneous. A true artist, who may rewrite their work many times, does not have this problem. I believe that understanding the impact of their words is a key sign of a real artist. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably did not think about how the use of long words made them powerful and showed his talent.

**Supermarket Opening**

Opening a new supermarket used to be a big event in Britain. You could always expect a celebrity, like a soap star or a member of the royal family, to come and cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets seem to open every day, and celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can open it for free? Last week, waiting customers did not care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were at the front of the line. According to one customer who knew someone working there, the first five men to enter would receive a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get a bunch of flowers. This news quickly spread through the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and causing envy among those who arrived late.

**Text: Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was released in 1941, there was a lot of excitement around it. However, it did not do well at the box office. It was only when it was shown on television that people started to remember it. This film has inspired many people to become filmmakers, which is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles believed that its success came from the fact that he did not know the rules of filmmaking, so he just went for it. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper owner who was similar to but not exactly like Hearst, Welles realized he had found the perfect role for himself as both director and actor, and he took the opportunity with great enthusiasm.

**Dermot and Carmel**

That morning, Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange. He had mentioned twice that he might be late and that he might stop at the golf club on his way home. He wanted to talk to someone, and that was the best place to do it. Carmel had nodded her head as if she didn’t really hear him. “Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?” he asked. She smiled and replied, “It’s funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I will walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it’s almost wrong to waste the day like this.” Dermot smiled back, saying, “You deserve to enjoy yourself. And if I’m late, I won’t need anything to eat, so don’t worry about it.” “That’s fine,” she said.

**Title Race**

“Tea boy? Do you mind? I’m a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.” Human nature can be very funny. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a well-known recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees believe that job titles create divisions among coworkers. Most surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would give up a pay raise for a more “motivational” or “professional” job title. If our desire for better titles is so strong that it overcomes our basic need for money, we are in trouble. In the early twenty-first century, no one wants to be called “subordinate.” The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just fancy words.

**The Vienna Assignment**

I was in Vienna to take photographs. This was usually the reason I traveled. Photography was more than just my job; it was a big part of my life. The way light fell on different surfaces always inspired me. I loved how one picture could capture the essence of a time, a place, or a person. I believed that one day, I might take the perfect photograph. As long as I had film in my camera, there was always a chance. I would finish one roll, load another, and keep looking with open eyes. This was my way of working, and I had followed it for a long time.

Once, I got lucky when a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became very popular. It was a brief moment of fame, but it was mostly just luck. They say you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work as a freelance photographer. It should have been a smart move, but life had other plans. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped, especially after my photo made it to the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photographs, and I was getting paid for it. That didn’t sound too bad to me.

The assignment came about by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*—which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a good payment for capturing the moods of my city in different seasons. I had my own style, showing daffodils in Hyde Park and the heat haze in Piccadilly. I knew that some of my best work would be ignored because it was just a picture book, not meant to challenge anyone’s views.

After a cold snap over Christmas, I submitted my winter photos of London and learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for reasons I didn’t need to know. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, while the French and Italian photographers were not. I was happy to go. Things at home were not good, so a week in snowy Vienna sounded perfect.

They put me up at the Europa hotel in the old city. I had last visited Vienna with my wife for a busy weekend of sightseeing. It had been hot and chaotic, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, alone in cold January, I knew it would be different. As soon as I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snow-covered roofs, I felt excited. I was ready to take great pictures.

On my first day, I didn’t even try to take photos. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to enjoy the atmosphere. The weather was cold, like the grand buildings from the old empire that shaped the city. I hadn’t seen what Schussner had done in the other seasons, and I didn’t want to. This was going to be my Vienna, and I was ready to discover it.

A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment. So, I took my time, looking carefully until I was ready. The next morning, I was out at dawn. The fresh snow meant Stephansplatz would be beautifully white and almost empty. I hadn’t figured out how to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its tall spire reached into the grey sky, while at ground level, it was massive and imposing. I realized I might have to settle for a partial view. In that weather and at that time, it could still be magical.

Photography has always had a sense of magic. Even the early photographers felt this before they fully understood the chemistry behind it. You can watch a blank sheet of paper turn into a photograph in a dark room. Even when you know how it works, the mystery remains. Perhaps that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me in a strange way.

**Text: Kinetic Art**

Exciting news: London's Hayward Gallery has changed into a place full of wonder. This change is not due to a big-budget show, but rather a unique look at a less-known part of the last 60 years. A new exhibition shows the history of kinetic art, which is art that involves movement, in the twentieth century. It shows that creating art that moves by itself or explores the idea of movement has been an important but often overlooked theme in creative work during this time. The exhibition features a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art, put together by curator Guy Brett, who has studied this topic for many years. Visitors can enjoy the art without too much text, allowing them to make their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. Some like it because it is figurative and easy to understand, while others enjoy the themes of leisure and escape from daily life. Some people might even be drawn to Hockney's charming personality and his clever comments that make him popular in the media. However, this popularity raises the question: does it mean his art lacks serious purpose? Some critics believe Hockney is an overrated artist. But one could argue that his popularity does not mean his work is unimportant. Hockney knows his own limits and believes it is not fair to judge his work based on a narrow idea of greatness. He does not claim to be a great artist and understands that only time will tell how he will be remembered.

**Window-shopping - an Art Exhibition**

In recent years, I have seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some not so good. What bothers me are shows that seem to push a specific idea, suggesting that certain artists share a common view. Sometimes this works, and we learn about new trends in seemingly unrelated works. More often, though, it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was different. Together with seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. 'Window-shopping' was meant to be a collection of individual artworks that connected only because they were all art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley filmed a video camera until it broke. These works did not fit into a specific theme and would not usually be shown together, but they did not interfere with each other and, I hope, added to each other's impact. I did not make any grand statements about contemporary art, but I believe that art is an individual activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it will ruin their enjoyment. Some believe that art historians, who focus on theory rather than practice, overlook the joy of looking at art and the special act of creating it. This idea is similar to thinking that knowing how a dish is made takes away from its taste. Understanding the importance of enjoyment does not mean we cannot also learn about the art we appreciate. In fact, knowing more about what we are viewing can enhance our pleasure. Additionally, pleasure is complex. How we feel and recognize pleasure is influenced by our senses and is shaped by the society we live in. While it is important to value our instinctive responses to art, the belief that thinking about art takes away from enjoyment is an outdated idea that once promoted art as a substitute for thought.

**Text: Metals**  
Stone Age people may have been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. While sitting by a river, waiting for fish, one of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow stone and picked it up. It felt different from regular stones and was very attractive. This could be how gold became important to early humans. Because gold is easy to shape, it quickly became a popular material. Copper might have also been discovered by chance. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they began to search for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This led to the development of metalworking, which improved the lives of our ancestors.

**St Ives**  
We were quiet as we carried our bags down the narrow, cobbled street that led to the town center. We bent down against the strong wind and tried to avoid the cold waves crashing over the walkway. The streets were empty, and all the windows in the cottages by the water were closed tightly against the storm. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. As the dark clouds gathered, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car did not seem like a good idea anymore. I had convinced my friend to come with me by promising beautiful walks along the Cornish coast and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is difficult because it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and those who faced wars and droughts are long gone. The reasons why they settled in certain places or formed families and communities are now forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We cannot go back in time to see what happened. However, computer modeling allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and environments and fill them with virtual communities—digital people that have some of the needs and abilities of real humans. We can set rules for them and create social groups. Then, we can change the weather or the population and see how these virtual cultures and their artificial people respond.

**Simplified Text:**

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth studied a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male monkey nearby. The stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean the dominant male would lose his position. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male made an alarm call that vervet monkeys use to warn of a leopard. The stranger quickly ran back to the trees. This happened several times throughout the day. However, the dominant male made a mistake. After using the alarm call successfully, he called out while walking across the open ground himself. 

**What Cats Catch**  
In a village in England called Felmersham, people collected information about what their cats caught. Over one year, seventy cats caught more than 1,000 animals. A professor in America estimated that all the cats in Britain might kill 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this number is not realistic because most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals than those in the survey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. In winter, many people feed birds, and gardens provide places for birds to nest, keeping their population above natural levels. The survey showed that cats are important predators, but they are not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to the marshmen, and they are treated with care. Each morning, the buffaloes, who have been sleeping near their owners, slowly leave to go to the reed beds beyond the water. They often groan about their tiredness before finally moving forward into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and relax, making low sounds of complaint. Their movements away from the house are slow and almost unnoticed, but eventually, they are swimming, looking tired. They spend the day among the reeds, grazing on green shoots.

**Picasso, Pablo**  
In 1940, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish while staying in the fishing port of Royan. One painting shows a fishmonger’s table with a crab and some soles. The fish look alive, but the painting is hard to read because Picasso used a flat pattern of overlapping shapes. The light colors and delicate brushwork create a calm underwater scene. However, there is a sense of tension as the fish seem to be ready to fight the crab. The sharp shapes in the painting suggest danger, giving it a deeper meaning.

**Text: Photography**

Over the last one and a half centuries, photography has been used to capture many aspects of human life and activities. In this relatively short time, photography has improved its ability to record moments in time and space, allowing us to see both large and small details. It has given us images from faraway places, distant parts of the solar system, and the social issues of modern life. Photography has become one of the most important ways to express what it means to be human.

However, the idea of recording events visually has a much longer history. The first pictorial records date back to the Upper Paleolithic period, about 35,000 years ago. We cannot be sure why early cave paintings were made. They might have recorded actual hunting events, served as magic to help with hunting, acted as religious symbols, or simply brightened daily life. Still, these images are closely connected to human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and what their role is in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has given special importance to visual images. When photography was invented in the mid-nineteenth century, it seemed to promise a truthful visual record. The camera was seen as a tool that worked like the human eye, capturing fixed images that closely resembled what we see. The chemical process used in photography allowed for the capture of natural scenes.

At the same time, photography was seen as a sophisticated cultural achievement, producing images that artists had worked hard to create. Ironically, because photography seemed so realistic, many believed that everyone could easily understand photographs. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander said that even the most isolated person could understand a photograph of the sky, whether it showed the sun, moon, or stars.

However, as global communication increased in the late twentieth century, we must consider how well photographs can cross cultural differences. Is photography limited by cultural norms like any other form of communication, such as language? Has our familiarity with photographs made us overlook the complex ways they convey vivid impressions of reality? 

Photography is often seen as providing convincing evidence, making it seem like a clear window into reality. It is common for someone to show a photograph and say, "This is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and the attitudes towards it have changed significantly. This change may be partly because photography has moved into what we might call "mythic time." Its original role as a record-keeper has evolved, and photographs, once closely connected to the photographer and the subject, have become historical documents. These images often tell us more about the people and society that created them than about the subjects themselves.

I want to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not only reflect culture; it can also inspire social and political change. For example, it is hard to imagine the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance in the fifteenth century without recognizing how the development of perspective changed visual representation. Similarly, photography has played a major role in creating the media culture of our time, while also revealing the harsh realities of the world.

**How to Write Poetry**

Teaching people how to write poetry can be tricky. It is important to be creative, but making one mistake can ruin everything. I do not want to act like I know everything, so I will say this: for someone who is just starting to write, reading a lot, writing often, and letting your imagination flow is more important than any advice. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others can write to escape their problems. Some writers follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration. All approaches are valid, as long as they are not just following strict rules. Finding your own voice is key; listen to your inner thoughts, nurture them, and let them grow. One day, your voice will be strong enough to stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, it is important not to have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used when necessary to explain something. A memory in the main character's mind can help move the story forward, but it should not slow down the action. Dialogue is very useful because it can show different sides of a situation quickly, keeping the reader interested. Too many words can ruin a short story, but being brief does not mean it should be just a summary. Conflict and action should be strong in a short story, just like in a novel, but every word must count.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay for a film is similar to playing chess. Most chess players make mistakes as they play. We may not know everything, but we know enough to play. We can sometimes see a few moves ahead, which feels good. As we learn more about chess, we realize that it is more about long-term strategy than short-term moves. We start to see the game as a whole, not just individual moves. We notice patterns in the game, like openings and end games. The more we play chess, the more we understand its complexities, just like in screenplay writing.

**Looking at Writing**

Humans naturally want to speak, as we see in young children, but no child is born knowing how to write. Charles Darwin said that language is a natural human instinct, but writing is not. Language exists in all societies, both now and in the past. While languages change, they do not necessarily get better. English is not more complex than the languages of ancient tribes. All healthy children learn to speak without lessons. When children are together without a common language, they create their own. In contrast, writing systems have been created only a few times in history and started as simple codes. Until recently, many children did not learn to read or write, and even today, some struggle. A group of children is unlikely to invent an alphabet, just as they would not invent a car engine. Children are naturally good at sounds, but learning to read and write is something that takes time and effort. We need to understand how writing works and how children learn so we can help them succeed.

Text: "I have never started a novel with so much doubt. If I call it a novel, it is only because I don’t know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and I do not end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader uncertain. This book is about my memories of a man I met only a few times, and I do not know much about what happened to him in between. I could create a more complete story by imagining what happened, but I do not want to do that. I just want to write down what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters in this story names I made up, and I have taken care to ensure that no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. He may never be famous. When his life ends, he might leave no more trace of his existence than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. However, the way he lives and the special qualities of his character may influence others, so that long after he is gone, people may realize that a remarkable person lived in this time. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know a little about his early life may find something useful in this book. I believe my book, with its limitations, will be a helpful source of information for my friend’s biographers. I do not claim that the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes of what was said, but I remember well what concerns me. Although I have put these conversations in my own words, I believe they represent what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the same liberty that historians take to create speeches for the characters that I did not hear. I did this to make the scenes more lively and believable, as they would be less effective if told only as facts. I want to be read, and I think I am justified in making my book interesting. The thoughtful reader will see where I have used this technique and can choose to ignore it. Another reason I feel nervous about this work is that the people I write about come from a different culture. It is hard to truly know people, and I believe you can only really know your own countrymen. People are shaped by many things: the place they were born, the home they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they liked, and the poets they read. All these experiences make them who they are, and you cannot understand them just by hearing about them; you must live them. You can only know them if you are one of them. Because you cannot fully understand people from a different country except by observing them, it is hard to give them credibility in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because you can describe characters more briefly there. You give the reader general ideas and let them fill in the details. In this book, I do not claim that my characters see themselves as they truly are; they are seen, like my main character, through my own perspective."

**POETRY RECITALS**

At any time in history, the world of literature can seem confusing to those living in it. However, later generations can see clear patterns and important figures in literature. Right now, there is a complex mix of different styles of poetry, various groups of poets, and different ways of presenting, criticizing, and teaching poetry. There are also many opinions about what a poet's role in society should be.

In general, the current discussion in contemporary poetry is about the mistrust and disagreement between serious 'literary' poets, who write poems meant to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer to perform their work for an audience. This division is not strict. Over the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common in many forms. Small literary groups in towns hold readings in village halls or members' homes. Schools and colleges invite poets to read and talk to students, and arts festivals often include poetry readings by well-known authors.

The effects of these events, where poets often have to perform in public, are varied and uncertain. For 'pop' poets, whose work is made for live audiences, performing is beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and can be understood quickly. However, when these poems are read on the page, their weaknesses in thought and technique become clear.

On the other hand, poets who are serious about their craft aim to create deep and meaningful work. They try to express strong emotions and ideas in a small space and use a variety of rhythms. Unfortunately, these poets may not be appreciated by audiences who are hearing their work for the first time. The risk is that they might only read their easiest poems, which may not represent their best work.

Attending poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry from a book, but it can be enjoyable and educational. Hearing good poets read their work aloud, even if they are not great speakers, helps the audience understand where to place emphasis. It is best if the audience has the text in front of them or knows the poems beforehand.

The main reason for popular poetry recitals, which sometimes include music, is to help audiences enjoy poetry and see it as an art form for everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**  
Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this approach has its challenges. It is overly simple to think that a person's story is a clear reflection of their past experiences. In an interview, both the interviewer and the interviewee influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to discuss. Even if the historian only listens, their presence can change how the informant remembers and talks about their past. The final result is shaped by the historian's social position and their understanding of history, which may also affect how the informant shares their memories. Historians must recognize their role in creating new evidence. The challenges continue even after the interview. The informant's memories are not always direct connections to the past. Their memories can be influenced by other sources, like the media, or by feelings of nostalgia or resentment about their childhood. These emotions can make the testimony seem more convincing, but they may actually come from later experiences rather than the time being discussed.

**Animal Science**  
There are two main ways to study animal science: the physiological approach and the whole animal approach. Physiologists focus on how the body works, including how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create complex behaviors. Those who take the whole animal approach study the behavior of animals in their natural environments and the factors that influence that behavior. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists usually work in labs studying a few species, like rats and pigeons, while ethologists study animals in the wild and their natural behaviors. Although these two areas are still somewhat separate, they are increasingly working together. Physiologists often claim that their methods are more fundamental. However, understanding how nerve cells work does not eliminate the need to study behavior itself, as behavior has its own structure and units that must be examined. Trying to explain a bird's nest-building behavior by only looking at nerve cells would be like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**  
Students studying social sciences for the first time face a challenge: they must learn both the content of their new subject and the methods used to study it. This means they need to understand not only the knowledge found in textbooks but also how that knowledge is gathered and organized. These two aspects are closely connected. While we all have experience with social life, social sciences go beyond common sense. Each social science focuses on a specific part of social life, uses particular research methods, and has its own key concepts. These concepts form the logical basis of the subject, allowing social scientists to move beyond everyday understanding and differentiate one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**  
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves Order, Arrangement, Proportion, Symmetry, Propriety, and Distribution. He also provides Greek terms for some of these ideas, likely based on earlier Greek sources that we no longer have. While utility and function are not part of his main definition, Vitruvius does discuss how to design buildings for different purposes. Initially, the focus is on the artistic side of architecture. The origins of classical architecture are complex, with a long history of simple structures, like huts, in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Although these early structures were not artistic, they contributed important elements that influenced later architectural designs. Despite their simple appearance, classical temples are essentially single-room huts.

The two sisters kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. She would drive around the gardens and the railway line, jumping over a small bridge with all four wheels in the air, which was Lily's only mistake. After that, they would pass the gasworks, where there was a strong smell. Chen, however, found it funny that his wife was driving without him knowing. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought men were strange. Her brother-in-law should have been upset, but instead, he was excited and made plans with Lily for a trip. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month, which was the quietest day of the week. They planned to leave early in the morning and return by midday so they wouldn’t lose any customers. In the meantime, Lily would practice driving. Despite her worries, Mui bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. However, Lily felt a bit insulted that Mui didn’t trust her navigation skills.

Within an hour of leaving home, they were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat ready to give directions, had to agree. On the road, Lily passed a couple of slow cars with great skill, and Chen even applauded her. After passing the gasworks in the seaside town, they drove smoothly along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a small street near the sea that had many empty spaces. She wasn’t sure about the road signs and preferred to pay for parking rather than risk getting a ticket. 

Lily noticed her sister’s worried face in the driving mirror. She thought it was better not to add to Mui's worries. Lily locked all the van doors and checked each one carefully. "Don't worry," Chen joked. "No one will want that old van." The sisters were annoyed. Lily told her husband he was ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too quick to judge. Surprised, Chen took Man Kee to look at the grey sea. He held his son close and thought about how he wanted to raise him. Chen wanted Man Kee to learn about business and own many restaurants one day. The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned for his son’s future.

He noticed smoke on the horizon and then saw a ship shining in the morning sun. Chen put a coin in a telescope and tried to find the ship. At first, he couldn’t see it, but then he finally spotted it. It was a small, old tramp steamer. Chen lifted Man Kee to the telescope. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It’s a special little ship for people like us. It may be small and old, but it will take us back home when we are done here. It will take you to your homeland, Son, which you have never seen." Chen kissed the top of Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui were behind them. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn’t want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the telescope stopped working. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and Lily was left watching seagulls searching for food in the water.

**THE WELL**

I had read that if you go deep enough into a hole, you can see the stars on a clear day. I convinced you to help me with my idea. You watched with wide eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and then climbed in. I asked you to let me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle, trying to help as I pushed the bucket off the side of the well. As soon as it was free, I fell down. You screamed and tried to stop it, but then you let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn’t realize I had achieved part of my plan. I saw strange lights, like the stars I usually saw in cartoons when a character got hurt. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say.

You called down to check if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, peeking at you through my eyelashes. You disappeared, calling for help. I waited a moment, then quickly climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge, landing on the courtyard stones. I heard alarmed voices coming from the castle's main door. I ran the other way, down to the passage leading to the moat bridge, and hid in the shadows. Mother and Father came with you and old Arthur; Mother was screaming and waving her hands. Father shouted for Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You stood back, looking pale and shocked. I was hidden in the shadows, feeling a rush of excitement. Then I noticed the drops of water I had left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots of dirty water on the dry stones. At my feet, the water had formed a small pool. I looked back into the courtyard, where Father was shining a flashlight down into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. Mother was now screaming loudly, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me deeply. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but now things were more serious than I expected. What started as a fun prank had turned into something that would lead to serious punishment, probably for me.

I regretted not thinking this through. In just a few minutes, my clever plan had turned into a disaster. Suddenly, I had an idea. I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, staggering out and blinking. I called out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit further and then fell dramatically on the stones. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I sighed and said, "Oh dear," smiling bravely. I claimed that I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat and crawled through it until I got out. I thought I was almost getting away with it until Father appeared in front of me. He made me repeat my story. I hesitated. His eyes narrowed. Thinking I was covering up a mistake, I said the secret passage had collapsed after me; there was no point in sending someone down to look for it. I said the well was dangerous and that I had barely escaped with my life. 

When I looked into my father's eyes, it felt like looking into a dark tunnel with no light at the end. It was as if he was seeing me for the first time, and I was seeing how the world looked from an adult's perspective. My words got stuck in my throat. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said, sounding more disappointed than I could have imagined. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked down at me, his face showing regret and concern. He seemed to want to shake his head, not because I had a scary adventure and my father didn’t believe me, but because he could see through my sad lie. He worried about my character and future because I had lied so easily. His pity felt like a harsh lesson, even more than what my father had given me, and it affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Now that her children are grown, Susan, who is a widow, must leave her family home. The van had the words 'Removers of Distinction' on it, and indeed, everything that made the house special was being taken away. Fred, the removal man, carefully packed all the fragile items, while his helpers were not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that looked over a small harbor. The memories of her children growing up there felt present in the air, like dust. When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" It was easy to miss the little boy he used to be, especially now that he was an adult helping with the move. He was making sure Susan didn’t mention the piano. Francesca, their daughter, was also helping, insisting that only she could take care of the Steinway piano.

Fred noticed Susan was not crying. "Do people cry?" she asked. "You'd be surprised," he replied. "They seem happy while packing, but then they cry in an empty room. They are fine once they get to the new place; it’s just hard to see everything taken apart." Susan understood that feeling. If she had been alone, she would have warned the movers about the piano before they started. But Robert insisted it was the movers' job to notice any problems. The piano was now the last item to be moved, sitting proudly in the best room of the house.

Sitting on the bottom stair, with all the chairs gone, Susan remembered the day they moved in. It felt like that day was playing in reverse. The piano had been the first thing brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for nearly two hours, and little Robert watched in amazement while Francesca cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano!" They had to find a way to get it inside, and her late husband, Peter, had solved the problem. They left the piano outside while they moved in the other furniture. The next day, a builder took out the first-floor window, and a crane was borrowed to lift the piano through the window. The children were overjoyed to see it come in, but it had cost a lot, and they couldn’t afford to have it tuned for months.

"That's that," Peter had said. "That's there forever." But forever is a long time. The children were too busy to visit often, and Susan found it harder to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and remembered that the banister rails were still not fixed properly. She should have warned the movers about the piano, but now it was too late. 

"Are you all right?" Fred asked her. "Just the piano left now, and then we’ll be done." Susan moved away from the stairs, feeling anxious. Robert and Francesca stood in the hallway watching. "No tears then?" Fred asked casually. She was close to crying. It was strange how moving things made them feel so important. Chairs, cups, and many other items that seemed unimportant before now felt full of emotion. Just then, the piano appeared at the top of the stairs, with Fred guiding it down. 

"Easy does it!" Fred called out as they carefully brought it down and placed it behind the van. Robert was the first to laugh, and soon they were all laughing together, relieved that it was over. As they walked down the path for the last time, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Text: Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**

**Do-it-yourself literary criticism: Is it just harmless fun?**

From the beginning, one of the main ideas of the Internet was to allow open access. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or share music online. However, in the early years, some technical skills were needed. Still, there was one area that became available to everyone: literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. 

Amazon's approach to book reviews was simple: anyone could share their opinion and give a book up to five stars. Each book had its own page, and when a reader wrote a new review, it appeared automatically. This allowed Amazon to have many free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought, instead of just relying on the publisher's description or professional critics.

Other online bookstores also offered similar features, but Amazon was the largest, with over 80% of the online market. This meant it had the most customers and received the most reviews, which sometimes led to problems. Thousands of reviews were submitted each day, and it was hard to check them all. A team of editors looked for reviews that followed Amazon's rules. For example, one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors were not allowed. Reviews that gave away the ending or mentioned other reviews were also banned. However, since reviewers could remain anonymous, it was easy for some to break the rules. 

For instance, some authors wrote positive reviews for their own books. One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the bad reviews of his first novel, so he wrote some good ones anonymously to balance things out. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed the fake reviews. Authors could also comment on their books by clicking a link that said, "I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book." Most authors used this to encourage readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses for direct communication. However, Amazon did not always check if these comments really came from the authors, except for well-known writers.

The real excitement came from readers, not authors. When James McElroy's book, *We've Got Spirit*, was published, it received good reviews from the press. But many people mentioned in the book felt hurt and used Amazon to express their anger. Many negative reviews appeared but were quickly removed. Despite this, Amazon saw the large number of reviews as good for business. 

Amazon wanted reviews to be a place to discuss books, not just a chat room. They paid special attention to bestselling books to ensure all reviews followed the rules. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to appear on pages for less popular books. For example, *The Story about Ping*, a classic children's book about a duck, inspired some humorous reviews because "ping" is also a term used in technology. One long review compared the book's story to Internet architecture, saying it gave a good overview of networking concepts. 

However, most reviews on Amazon were serious. They provided a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books made it hard to have real feelings about them. This is why making literary criticism available to everyone is a positive change.

**Text: Art in Modern Times**

In modern times, especially over the last two hundred years, we often think that every artist must go against the art of their time. Art is praised for being unique, revolutionary, and sometimes shocking. We feel good about admiring artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. However, when we look at art today, we often say that some artists have gone too far and that their work is not really art anymore. The media often expresses these feelings for us, and we tend to agree because we expect to be confused by the newness of art. We do not notice the old themes and methods that are still present in today’s art. We want artists to be different from us, with special talents that break the rules. In the past, people commissioned artists for specific purposes, and art was part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to work alone and sometimes get upset if they try to connect with us.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and then ask an important question about it. An artist chooses a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about the variety of pictures and asks, "What are they all about?" It then states, "There is no end to the different kinds of pictures." This language seems childish, but stay with me. After choosing the text, the artist asks someone to prepare a canvas for him and then to take it to a sign painter. He tells the sign painter to write the chosen text on the canvas in simple black letters without making it fancy. The sign painter does this. So, my important question is: is the final product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26, there is an unspoken rule for painters: once you find a successful style, you should stick to it. Collectors expect artists to keep creating in the same way, and if they try something new, people often feel disappointed. I’m not sure why this is the case. Gallery owners prefer safe choices, and perhaps art buyers feel more comfortable with familiar styles. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, have successfully tried new things. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is now trying something different, and we will see if he succeeds. His new show changes from the still lifes he is known for to paintings of the London Underground. Rimmington finds a special charm in railways. He started with drawings of Kings Cross Station in the 1980s and then moved underground to explore what happens below. These sketches have inspired his exhibition called Underground Encounters, which features 40 paintings and drawings that show the unique beauty of this hidden world.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I do not know why I say "escape." The villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to recover. So, I have come here to heal myself. Besides an old peasant who comes daily to clean, I am quite alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel like I am floating in my memories. I talked about the uselessness of art but did not mention its comforts. The comfort of my work lies in the fact that in the silence of a painter or writer, reality can be changed and shown in a meaningful way. Our everyday actions are like a rough cover hiding the true meaning beneath. For artists, art allows us to deal with the pain of daily life, not to escape it, but to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why should we hurt one another?

**Family Business**

"Look, this isn't good!" said my Dad. We were in the car on our way back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice beside him, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for the best end-of-school exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, although I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford." "So?" I replied, trying to act tough. "Mightn't that be useful?" 

"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a serious talk was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. "I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else!" "And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand a lot of information, you are good at talking, and you enjoy performing." "I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see on TV."

"Anyway," he said, getting serious, "I feel like your heart isn't in the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us." The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by my father's expectations. I could see many career options, and I wanted to explore them. But I also didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I still found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly. "I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," my father said, who often turned out to be right about these things. "It's a pity because you have the talent - the brains, the courage, the vision." "There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business. "Anyway," I added, "you could always use me as a consultant." 

My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and since he was motherless, I took care of him. It wasn't hard; I loved him. Because the business was successful, we lived comfortably - in a big house in London, attended nice schools, wore good clothes, and went to parties, theaters, and operas. My father knew many interesting people - politicians, actors, and businessmen - and our home was always lively.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me." "OK," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate choices, especially the sadness my father would feel if I disagreed with him. This was how he controlled us.

So, it happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always with easier tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father came to visit me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I focused and organized my thoughts, he might be right. I felt ready and confident. But then my father told me that he needed me to do one last important task for the family business, and he promised it would be worth my time.

"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now." I could tell my father didn't understand the pressure I was under (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him), and he would see my refusal as a betrayal. 

As he explained the task, I saw more clearly than ever how focused my father was - the way he approached his work with energy and control. In his own way, he was a genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important. "All right," I said. "I'll do it."

**Simplified Text:**

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. A house that requires strict budgeting is often not worth buying at all. However, at the time, it seemed like a good and desirable choice. Simon had been successful in his work, and cases were coming in regularly. Lois returned to her job at the advertising agency two months after the twins were born and received a raise that brought her salary to thirty-five thousand. She strongly wanted to move, and Simon did not resist her arguments, which seemed convincing at the time: their flat was not suitable for a family, they needed more space, a garden, and a separate room for an au pair. They could have found these things in a less expensive area of London, but Lois wanted more than just extra space. Mornington Mansions was not a good address for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. Lois felt that even saying the name of their old flat lowered her social status.

Lois decided that one of them should use public transport to save money. Since her office was on the other side of London, Simon had to be the one to travel by tube. The crowded journey made him feel envious and unhappy, and he often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had stayed as a boy. He remembered the smell of dinner, his grandmother's care for his tired grandfather, and how she made his life easier. She had been a supportive lawyer's wife, always present at legal events and seemingly happy with her life. But that world was gone. Lois had made it clear before they married that her career was just as important as his. This was a modern marriage, and both of their jobs were essential for their lifestyle. Their home, the au pair, and everything depended on both of their incomes. 

Now, their hard work could be ruined by Venetia, who had come to their office in a bad mood. Something had upset her, and she confronted Simon with intense anger. He regretted not leaving his room earlier; if he had, she might have calmed down and thought things over. He remembered her angry words: "I defended Brian Cartwright today. He told me that when you were his lawyer four years ago, you knew he bribed three jurors. You did nothing. Is that true?" Simon replied, "He's lying. It isn't true." She also accused him of knowing that Cartwright had given shares to his fiancée before the trial. Simon denied it, but his denial sounded unconvincing even to himself. He felt guilty and ashamed, remembering the fear of punishment from his school days. When he looked into her eyes, he saw her disbelief. 

He wished he had said, "Cartwright told me after the trial, but I didn't believe him. He will say anything to make himself look important." Instead, he had told a more dangerous lie, and she knew it was a lie. But why was she so angry? What did his past actions have to do with her? Why was Venetia acting as the judge of their legal practice? Was her own behavior always perfect? Did she have the right to ruin his career? He was unsure of what she could do, but if this rumor spread, it could destroy him.

Text: 'I chose this place to live because I thought I would be anonymous among people who didn’t care if the rented houses were falling apart or if the gardens were messy. I was wrong. People in the shops, who are living their real lives, soon start to recognize you. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, trying to forget that summer is happening outside, but tonight, I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have trimmed the rosemary and lemon balm to make space for a chair, and my arms are tingling with scratches. It is a small London garden, where plants must grow tall or spread out to survive. 

“Been doing some clearing, I see,” says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leaning out of the window. She is a writer with several unpublished manuscripts, and I sometimes help her with them as an English teacher. I have a copy of her latest manuscript now. “How’s the work going, Jaz?” 

“For goodness sake. In no other job do people ask you about your work so many times a day,” she replies. Then she adds, “I’ve got something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down.” I don’t want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 

“So, you’re on holiday now, you lucky person,” she says, sitting in shorts and a tank top on the chair while I drop a cushion onto what used to be a small lawn. “Cheers,” she says, feeling young. “I should’ve gone into teaching – a writer doesn’t have holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.” And then there are those who can do neither. 

“So, what are your plans for the holidays?” All my worries about the end of the school year come rushing back. Empty days. Hot pavements covered in melting chewing gum. The walk to the shops and back. The little park with its fountain, and loneliness sitting beside me on the bench. “Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. I’ve been meaning to ask if you could feed the cats.” My heart races as I say this. “Of course I will,” Jaz replies, knowing she will be around. “So where will you stay? A nice bed and breakfast?” 

“No. I’ll be staying with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were eight.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with fiction. “Going back to your roots. So what do you think of it so far? My work?” My silence makes Jaz ask about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which is half-read on my desk. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and delivering rejected manuscripts to hers. 

Something makes me speak honestly for once. “Let me give you a little tip,” I start. “What?” she asks, surprised. “Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good: a little less self-centeredness, a bit more fiction…” 

“Teachers!” Jaz replies, acting like a rebellious student about to take back a poorly graded paper. “I keep a journal, I have for years, where I write something good, no matter how small, about each day.” My words sound as old-fashioned as my dress. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” 

Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes and come back home, reading on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives me a moment of comfort, but suddenly I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, closing one eye in a strange wink as she said, “I’ve had my moments.” We nearly died laughing.'

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and hearing stories about their lives. However, there is also a need to learn about our wider past to help us understand our future, both as individuals and as a nation. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity; knowing about the past helps us feel secure about the future. Just as we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture that has been passed down through generations. There may be parts of our national heritage that we do not like, but it is still a part of who we are, and it can be comforting to feel connected to something larger. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being. It influences everything from our customs to our material culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, in modern society, many of these oral traditions have been lost. Now, we often look to places and buildings to understand our past. It is very important to preserve these connections as a way to honor our ancestors' identities.

**The Fens**

Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*, where the landscape of a region in England called the Fens became very important. After the book was published, people asked me why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the area, chose to write about it. The simple answer is that I found the Fens interesting because they seemed quiet and empty, providing a blank canvas for my story. However, I learned that the Fens are not truly flat or empty. They are uniquely English but also strangely different. It is surprising that there is a place in the middle of England that many people find unfamiliar, especially since many other areas of Britain have become part of the national culture. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, seemingly simple yet deeply mysterious. While writing my novel, I did not explore the Fens extensively; I have never visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer to imagine worlds rather than seek strict proof. However, trying to imagine the Fens is logical because, as shown in Edward Storey's book, the Fens are not just a landscape but also a way of thinking.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant just putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility should mean more than that. Displays can be engaging and use creative techniques to attract visitors and evoke emotions. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, some museums provide loan boxes of objects for teachers, and they have started offering similar materials for elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real objects, not replicas. They exist to provide a genuine experience with items that have historical significance. This is their strength and what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CDs. Museums that meet this challenge and create exciting displays and outreach programs will find that their competition in "virtual history" can actually help them by increasing interest in real historical items.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen quickly and on a large scale, affecting many of us. This can make some people very focused on preservation and encourage others to think more about the nature of our towns and their future. It can be argued that people who have lived through significant events, like world wars, are more likely to value preservation than earlier generations. Anything that represents stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change is not a problem if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect social changes, such as population growth, welfare, and our needs.

**Text: Einstein**

If you stop anyone in the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will likely think of Albert Einstein. His image is often used to sell products like computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about what Einstein actually did, except that he created some complex theories called 'relativity', which are known for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem to go against everyday experiences. 

Einstein was part of a major change in scientific thinking, a revolution that started modern science in the twentieth century. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to create a new, clearer description of the universe by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

When we were children, Lydia and I did not trust any book that won awards because we thought it would be boring. Our mother often criticized us for this attitude, but our father would give us small coins for each chapter we read to encourage us to look at better books. He would also include some good books in our Christmas and birthday gifts, marked with a note saying, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we thought most of his choices were 'boys' books', he did introduce us to some shorter works of good fiction and, once, to a famous collection of poems.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851, 'The origin of human language is truly secret and wonderful.' This secret has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller claimed in 1928 that 'primitive man' might have made sounds like "meuh" when he sensed danger. This sound is sad. The early humans who traveled through dangerous lands made desperate noises, and some of these sounds are still present in words today, like 'malaria', which means "fever", or the Latin word 'mors', which means "death". 

Many people avoided discussing the origin of language, thinking it was a topic for odd theories. However, recently, the study of how language began and evolved has become very important. Language likely developed in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, speech was mainly used for friendly communication and was a key tool in struggles for power. Sharing information was probably not the main purpose of language, which goes against the ideas of philosopher John Locke, who described language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

**Text: Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode looks at how to write reviews from the perspective of someone who does it. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. There are strict deadlines and limits on how long they can be. Once published, they are only read for a short time—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this, many people think that writing reviews is not very important. Often, both the public and the writers believe that people only write reviews because they need money or because they cannot spend all their time on a novel or a serious book. 

However, writing reviews is a skilled job that requires different abilities. Writing a short review of six or eight hundred words for a newspaper is different from writing a longer review of six or eight thousand words for an international journal. A review in a weekly magazine, which is about fifteen hundred words, has challenges from both short and long reviews. 

Reviewers must think about their audience. Some readers may only skim the review, while others may be very interested in the topic and want a detailed article. Reviewers also need to know a lot about different subjects and must write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This means that most reviewers also write other things besides reviews.

The American writer John Updike, who does not think highly of criticism, still enjoys writing reviews when he is not working on his novels. He collects all his reviews, no matter how short, into books with modest titles. Some might think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last long, but it is understandable if they want their work to be remembered, especially if they believe some of their best writing is in their reviews. I feel this way about my own work too. 

My main job has been in academia, and most of my serious books are academic, which professors are expected to write. However, in the English-speaking world, there is not a strict difference between reviewing and literary study, so it is common for the same people to do both. The time has passed when academics criticized professors for writing reviews, thinking it was a waste of time or not dignified. Complaints from non-professors about professors taking away their opportunities to write reviews are also less common now. This is partly because there are many more reviews being written today, so almost anyone can write one, and also because there are fewer opportunities available.

I believe this situation is good for both readers and professors. Readers can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about, and for professors, writing reviews helps them stay connected to the public. It also reminds them that they need to communicate clearly with non-professors. When they talk to each other, they may use complicated language, but when they write for a general audience, they need to be clear. 

In conclusion, despite its importance, reviewing is usually a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he entered the dark, quiet hallway, he felt a brief sense of ownership that still surprised him after three years. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, wondering what had happened while he was away. The flat felt like a welcoming place, a space where he could focus without distractions. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or broken pipes, but his flat always seemed to be waiting for him, looking either independent or neglected, depending on how tidy he had left it.

Over time, he began to see it as an extension of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He grew frustrated with its inability to change. There were always a few letters piled up by the door and the answering machine blinking with messages when he returned. He was thankful that his windows were intact and that nothing had been stolen, but he often wondered what the flat would look like if something bad happened.

From his dull office on the third floor, Ralph looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After leaving the busy office, he felt a bit more like himself on the bus ride home, but he still struggled with the need to be alone, even though he craved company. At his desk, he wanted solitude and time to enjoy his belongings, but once he escaped, he felt empty and lost. He suspected that his job, which didn’t suit him, had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was.

He often read or listened to music at night, but he started to wonder for whom he was doing these things. His thoughts became unclear, and he felt disconnected. He remembered a time when he felt more in control and believed he could have changed his situation if he had recognized his own worth. However, he had been so eager to find something that he followed the first opportunity that came his way, as if it was meant to be.

After university, he tried to make a plan for a better life, but he was not surprised to find that he only wanted to get by. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following them as they moved forward, unable to see how he could find happiness in his work. He went to one job interview, grateful for the chance, but he didn’t think to evaluate the job itself, which was a vague editorial position at a local free newspaper. After a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, he didn’t consider the long-term challenges he would face. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who had applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

You are not alone. Making a presentation requires different skills than running a company, but more senior executives are expected to be good at it. **Simplified Text:**

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient with mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will not turn out right. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will just get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some things can be done faster, like solving crossword puzzles or doing math in your head. But other things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they may fail, like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.

Sometimes, saying "Think fast; we need results" is not helpful, just like trying to get a good night's sleep in a short time. We learn, think, and understand in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds. There are three main speeds of thinking. 

The first is faster than thought. Some situations need an immediate reaction. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to keep me safe, and only later did I think about what happened. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer also does not have time to think about their next move. This quick reaction can be called our "wits."

The second speed is thought itself. This involves figuring things out, weighing options, and solving problems. A mechanic trying to fix a car, a scientist interpreting results, or a student working on an assignment are all using this type of intelligence, which we often call "intellect." People who are good at solving these problems are seen as "bright" or "clever."

The third speed is slower and less direct. It is more relaxed and dreamy. In this mode, we think about things slowly, like when we are daydreaming or meditating. Sitting on a rock by the sea, listening to the waves, is a different mental state than planning a meal or writing a letter. This slow way of thinking is just as important as the faster types. Taking time to think is necessary, especially when life gets busy. 

Some everyday problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some complex issues can only be understood with a relaxed attitude. Recent studies show that slower thinking is good for understanding complicated situations. Deliberate thinking works well for clear problems. For example, deciding where to go on holiday is usually straightforward. But when we are unsure about what to consider or when the issue is complicated, we need to use our slow thinking.

If the problem is how to manage a difficult team at work or whether to change careers, it may be better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have long understood the limits of fast thinking and have tried to develop slower ways of knowing. Recently, scientists have begun to study these slower ways of thinking. The field of cognitive science is showing that our unconscious mind can do many interesting and important tasks if given enough time. It can learn patterns that our conscious mind might miss, understand complex situations, and solve difficult problems better than quick thinking can.
