Text: Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner from Britain, visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is located ten miles south of the equator, on a mountain path that leads to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. For the past three years, this beautiful but isolated place, called Nanyuk, has been my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners before. On my fourth trip to Kenya, I decided to change that. I participated in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after I finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss. 

Training at high altitude helps produce more red blood cells, which improves how well the body carries oxygen. This has helped many generations of Kenyan runners succeed. My first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent, in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience for me, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, and all but three were Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I know that Kenyan success is not just because of the altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple and effective approach to running. They run effortlessly, eat a simple diet, and enjoy competing.

During my time at the training camp, I learned how the Kenyan runners train. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The living conditions are basic; the athletes share rooms in dormitories with six people. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. Each day starts at six in the morning, and we gather to hear instructions from the coaches. We were told to "run easy" because we had a tough day ahead. We covered about 40 kilometers each day, which is just under a marathon distance. Sundays were easier, with only one run of 20 kilometers.

Life at the camp was simple. We only needed a splash of water on our faces and a quick brush of our teeth before breakfast. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs, eaten in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to a stream to wash off in the evening. By the end of my stay, I had a deeper understanding of why Kenyan runners are so successful. Their success cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simple lifestyle in the mountains, the hard training, and their passion for running might be the true reasons behind Kenya's success in distance running.

**Text: The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem is not just because of the recession; advertising started to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The issues with advertising are more serious and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large markets and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Even campaigns for big brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen a year. If you buy a new car, it is likely provided by your employer, and if not, you may only buy one every three years. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you consider all the different products and services, it is very likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In comparison, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are listed and analyzed. The average person buys about 400 of those 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are because of advertising. This means that only about 4 percent of advertising is effective. 

When you watch TV tonight, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. For most people, this number is about one in 16, or 6 percent. This means that the commercials for the other 15 brands, or 94 percent, are likely wasted. You might think you are different and that you are not influenced by advertising, but most people feel the same way. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. 

There is always some waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many advertisements have shown that it can work. Advertising needs to reach a large number of people to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as advertisers cannot know in advance who will be interested. 

Even with careful targeting, advertisers can reduce waste but can never know exactly who will respond. Unlike face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every potential customer, this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would communicate with them directly instead of using mass media. 

Any advertiser who can attract one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is doing well. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be very happy with a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach 2 percent of the population would be considered very successful, and this is just a small part of the population. While mass media can be a cost-effective way to reach people, if advertising is to improve, its messages will need to be more focused than ever before.

**Simplified Text:**

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Greenest Home**

Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting features. First, it is home to Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral. Writers who care about the environment admire the 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in the cathedral's thirteenth-century chapter house. 

The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. This house is known as Britain's greenest home. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into compost for their garden, and heat their home using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. 

You might not notice the traditional-looking house, which has a clay tile roof, located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the burnt-orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and received approval from planners, even though it is in a conservation area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will find complete silence. The house is very well insulated, with special triple-glazed windows that keep out noise. 

Once inside, and after taking off your shoes (as Robert asks), you will feel a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it ventilates the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create air movement because the house is designed to be draught-proof. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They started by designing a building that produced no carbon dioxide. Then they decided to also avoid using mains water. They created composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not have a dishwasher because they believe using strong detergents is wrong.

Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness." The only medieval feature of the house is its design: the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, goes up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.

Soon, the house will use even less electricity when they install £20,000 worth of solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will generate extra electricity, enough to charge an electric car in the future. The only heating source is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they say they only use during the coldest winter days.

When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no draughts and everything was at the same temperature. He mentioned that a woman from the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggested that people living in old houses should return to how people lived back then, but this idea might be hard for many to accept.

The secret of the house is that it is low-tech and simple, so there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were bought from a local builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen, making the house affordable to build. It cost the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are not interested in this idea.

Text: 'The Camera Never Lies

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational man and even a scientist. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof that these tiny creatures existed. He published these photographs with an article where he accepted fairies as magical beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The results were very beautiful. But this simple trick challenges a basic idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and always has been able to. Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the moment cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Text: Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured the human imagination, and the people who work with it have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were respected like doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron designs.

In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more creative approach to interior design. Still, much of the work looks similar, with manufacturers of gates and balconies advertising their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks with odd designs. Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmithing craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently."

Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it more easily. "In short," says Dawson, "these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork, according to Dawson. His own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space," he explains.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's quite magical because it's very soft when hot, but as soon as it cools, it becomes hard and unmovable again." Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles that seem inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, and another resembles a Celtic cross. "I love that steel is cold and hard," she says. "It feels like it will last forever." No other metal can provide as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for the next thousand years, as long as we don’t have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING'**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was strange for me too. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I had not planned to stop smoking, and I didn’t really want to. I felt annoyed by the constant pressure from anti-smoking groups, and I still do. I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop myself; that wouldn’t be fair." I thought it was reasonable because I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me pleasure. The counsellor looked at me as if she understood. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. 

What happened was that the messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge because of the pressure to stop, the idea of quitting started to seem appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that was just for me. Could I also achieve other things? In many ways, it was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be hard without cigarettes, but it was not a problem at all. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, doing simple things at home on weekend mornings was the hardest part, and it still is. 

I am starting to think that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. All these moments were times when I would have smoked.

**Simplified Text:**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond positively, I know they are aware of her achievements. 

Dorothy Hodgkin should be well-known because she won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964. She was a remarkable person and her life shows important changes in the 20th century, such as the growth of women's education and the global sharing of scientific knowledge. 

When I started my research, I wanted to read biographies of scientists. A friend suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of Hodgkin and also worked in science. However, I found that there were no biographies of Pauling in the local bookshop. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes for both chemistry and peace.

Some scientists believe that biographies of scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel Prize winner, said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers feel the same. This idea that scientists are less interesting than artists or writers is common, but it is not true. 

Some scientists are now appearing in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out prizes on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car advertisements. These activities help people see scientists as real people, not just researchers.

The way scientific biographies are written is also changing. In the past, they were often boring and focused only on work. However, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show that scientists can have interesting lives outside of their work. 

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her science. She solved the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize, and also worked on insulin. She balanced her scientific career with her personal life, raising three children and being married to a husband who was often away for work. 

Her personal life may not seem directly related to her science, but it shows how she managed different parts of her life. There is much to learn from her story, including her passion for science. 

Communicating this passion is a challenge for biographers. Many readers may not understand complex scientific ideas without clear explanations. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort. 

It is unfortunate that many educated people do not recognize the important contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, while they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

**Text: Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers whose wells have dried up are now asking for her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she only needs her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is called dowsing. There are many ideas about how it works, from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ones. One of the most believable ideas is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can sense these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to drought, Margaret has been very busy, sometimes having a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with remote cottages or barns that are now holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes over long distances. There are also golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She says, "You can't drill a well where there is a risk of waste getting into the water supply. The water we find is in cracks of solid rock, and if we bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, Cornwall has many minerals, so we need to be careful about iron."

Another important factor is electricity to run the pump, which can be costly if the well is far from power sources. After considering these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. "I hold the pendulum still and move it gently over the map. It will swing when it is above an area with water."

Once she has identified possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick points. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also checks the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill until they find a common agreement.

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in her unique skill; many researchers and writers have been interested in this mysterious ability. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain why she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard for her family to continue their well-drilling business year after year.

**Simplified Text: 'We Changed Lives for a Day!'**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be fun to try something new! We arranged this for four people - read about their experiences.

**A. Amanda's Story**

I had never been to a place like the restaurant where my friend works. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. It was very different from my hometown, and I was nervous! Being a mother is busy, but working as a waitress was even harder! I had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when I tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. I felt so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said it happens to everyone.

By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers waiting to get in, and I felt really nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but luckily, everything was done with computers. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn’t get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say, "Pardon?" which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was completely tired and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. One waitress told me it had been a 'quiet' day, and I couldn’t believe how tiring waitressing was. I thought it was an easy job, but you need to be friendly and able to handle many customers at once. I’m quite shy, and I don’t think I could work on a busy Saturday night. I wasn’t happy with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very glad to go back to my children. Taking care of them seems easy after waitressing!

**B. Cindy's Story**

I was a bit nervous about being a 'mum' for a day, but I was also excited. I had heard that Amanda's daughters were cheeky, but I thought I could manage. As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, quickly shopped at the supermarket, and took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble began. They turned the couch into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming loudly! I thought they would get tired, but I was wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they wore me out! After a lot of convincing, I got them to bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun started! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew they were just trying to come downstairs to watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never realized how tiring it could be to take care of two small children. You don’t have a moment to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's Story**

On the farm, I wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a treat! I was unsure how to dress for school. I hoped I wouldn’t stand out too much. At assembly, I looked at about 400 students and hoped I blended in. Then it was time for a math class. The children worked in small groups, which was different from my school days when we had to recite together! I helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There is so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson, which was nice, and then a French lesson where the children wanted to practice with me, showing how rusty my French was! Finally, we had Physical Education. I was exhausted, but the children had so much energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I will stick to farming!

**D. Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which are sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers, making ice cream, and putting on labels. It was hard not to eat some!

At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and helped a sheep that had fallen over. If sheep are left for more than 12 hours after falling, they could die, so they need to be checked every day. It must be tough in winter! After feeding the calves, I started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, every day of the year! I found it lonely and missed the children - animals don’t talk back! The hardest part of the job is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, so it’s hard to plan any time away. Rosemary will only get about three days off this year. Farming seems nice, but the reality is very different. The income is not steady, and I wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

**Simplified Text:**

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is surprising how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who do not play music, grew up in a rural area of southern Sweden. At the age of 30, he has become a unique trumpet player in the world. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by forgotten composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces.

When you meet him, he looks young and lively, just like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls. A television program was also made about his work and growth, filmed in both London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo, and his music career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and Hakan never stopped playing.

His mother found the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra and convinced him to give Hakan lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, quickly recognized Hakan's natural talent. Hakan is grateful to have had such a passionate teacher from the beginning, someone who loved the trumpet and sought out players from around the world. 

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. There will always be some flaws, and no two mouthpieces are exactly the same. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, Hakan had a special ability to find the right balance and connect with the trumpet. He says that even as a child, his unique sound was already noticeable.

Unlike John Wallace, another famous trumpet player from Britain who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hakan has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also did not play in an orchestra. Hakan collected all of Andre's records, and his parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player.

When Hakan was 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous. Instead, at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud agreed with Hakan's view that playing in an orchestra was not for him, comparing it to gardening. Hakan knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special talent for connecting with the audience.

Thibaud suggested Hakan enter the competition for experience. Hakan prepared only for the first round but made it to the second. Fortunately, he already knew most of the pieces for that round too. However, in the final round, he faced a concerto that made him nervous. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even if he felt he played poorly, people still listened to him.

Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but that is not true. He thoughtfully avoids trying to explain what makes his communication special, saying, "You risk destroying it by trying to explain. The power of music is that it can always move people."

**Text:**

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insight, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unusual friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures a mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her child.

**C.** This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long and quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after the Second World War, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After his recent success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies and has a lively companion, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie helps her navigate her relationships with suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary moments of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright spots of human experience.

**E.** Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what a typical workday is like for them.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I’m operating, but I do worry about what I will do the next day. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it is successful, it feels amazing, which makes up for the times it doesn’t work. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see outpatients and explain the surgeries to them. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to patients. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I worry for the first few days about my patients, and I often dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train to work, and arrive at 9:15 am. At 10:30 am on Mondays, we meet to discuss our work, any problems, or if anyone needs help. I work in a team with three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only 10 to 15 percent being design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they agree, we work on budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people, and it’s important to communicate well. When their work comes in, I put everything together and send it to the printers. Managing several projects at once can be very stressful. Deadlines are always close, and my days are not the same. I have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we often go to the pub. If a client likes my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but sometimes it’s 8:30 pm or later. I find it hard to relax when I’m busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am most days, but two or three mornings a week, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long-haul flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I have to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and just snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which helps me plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. However, most are well-behaved, and I have a good relationship with my regular clients. Sometimes, I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I need to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. Around 11 am, we get hungry and go to a local café for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I have a home office, so when I get back, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants their garden designed, I usually set up a meeting in the evening around 7 pm or 8 pm. We focus on using old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes, clients have very specific ideas, which can be challenging. However, it’s very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone ring. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows me to be creative."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. I am the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site workers and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I have lunch for about half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. The contractors have set meal times, so when they are eating, I can check things on site. Since we check their work, it can create tension, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent comes up, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Text: Careers - Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am to reach the office by 7:30 am. I manage customer development programs for our credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to discuss any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that people are sharing their hard work, so I try to give helpful feedback. I can tell if the sound fits our record label. Once I sign a band, we start working on their first album, choosing songs, a producer, and additional musicians. I also share my vision of the album with the marketing team. I manage budgets and spending. I leave work by 7:00 pm at the earliest, and most evenings I go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups in one night. After a concert, I might visit an artist in the studio. Most of my social life is connected to my work, and I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the schedule for client meetings, and wait to see who arrives. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and love making sales, knowing the furniture is going to a good home. We sell antiques priced from £1,000 to £6,000, buying from auctions, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, and I work closely with restorers, gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business and often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it usually takes me about an hour to relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift pattern. When I have an early shift, I leave home at 6:00 am. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift and control one of the four positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, so I work for about an hour and a half at one station, take a half-hour break, and then switch to a different station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I often read about new air traffic rules between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. It’s important to stay alert in this job, so if I feel unwell, I don’t hesitate to take a sick day. The work can be stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. The first thing I do is start the electronic point-of-sale system. I make sure someone is watching the register and coordinate lunch and break times for staff. In the morning, I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to quickly gather many books for them. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers’ representatives visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the upcoming months. I need to think about how many copies of a title we might sell. When we want to feature a new title, I ensure it arrives on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Two days a week, I work a late shift, during which I close the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. First, I contact our freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, so I try to warn clients about potential problems in those countries. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with our editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second deadline is 11:00 am, so I need to work quickly. I type the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and then make any necessary changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax, so I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Text: Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What makes a good leader?**  
A leader inspires others and helps create change. They guide people towards a common goal. Leadership is not about being tall or having a high IQ. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is very important, and a good leader should be able to express their ideas clearly and confidently. Dixon says, "It's having the confidence to say 'I believe' instead of 'I think.'"

B. John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, believes that "Most people have more potential for leadership than they realize." Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it is easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for good management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and provided support. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and kept information from you. When things went wrong, they blamed you. The first leader led well; the second just managed poorly.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes, "A good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a company, a sports team, or a country."

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Find out what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired, use that energy to take action.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes strong leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you usually negotiate, try taking the lead. Notice how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and strive to achieve them. Look at your job demands and identify where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career.

F. Leadership does not just happen. It develops through taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate and motivate, organize and guide, praise and encourage.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will always be accepted. It might even push people away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your contribution is essential and how you can help others become leaders.

**Simplified Text: Films on Video**

**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent releases**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The friendly banter and brave attitude of foreman Bud and his team remind us of tough heroes in movies by Howard Hawks. The film's design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are weak. Despite the skill in making the film, the story feels like a simple B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, is an interesting contrast to Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's film is more traditional, focusing on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments. The flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife is done with a harshness that some may find more effective than Malick's softer images.

**C. On Guard**  
This film, based loosely on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, is a fun swashbuckler that stands out among musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain who causes trouble behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is an energetic hero, and although Daniel Auteuil is a bit too serious for a light film, he also has his good moments as a swordsman. The filmmakers use costume-drama clichés with so much humor and charm that it doesn’t matter.

**D. Character**  
This serious story is set in early 1900s Rotterdam. The detailed production and costumes make the film look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is cruel when evicting tenants. His difficult relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on the period details and not enough on the dark themes.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skill. The sound editing is especially good; every footstep, creaking floorboard, and barking dog is clear. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act selfishly in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
The publicity for this three-hour war epic boasts "Forty-eight International stars." With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where battle-hardened soldiers wait for news about the invasion, are slow for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is impressive in terms of logistics, it is best seen on the big screen. Watching it on video is a less exciting experience.

**Simplified Text:**

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is very interesting. The main character is a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife when she is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending has a surprising twist. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. It follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the rich people of the Italian Renaissance, as he gets involved in politics, church secrets, and serious crimes. We always believe he will find out who is guilty. The story is complicated, and the book is a bit too long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is a tax inspector. She is in a good position to investigate when a strange man dies in front of her. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, Leah is brave and skilled, making her a great character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and while there are not many deaths, there is more thinking than usual. Parker always provides high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has her usual detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, looking into an attack and robbery at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and attention to unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock.
