**Style Merchants**

Style affects many parts of our lives today, from clothing to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares some trends for this year's fashion lovers.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the overly frilly look, and instead choose simpler styles. Ingham has been designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to cut and make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs long, classic evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue summer suit, which has been a staple in women's wardrobes for most of the 20th century, but he makes it look fresh and new.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous people seek her jewellery. Her unique style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by the 18th century. Recently, she has started using diamonds. "It must reflect my age," says 36-year-old Quail. "I reached the moment when I wanted a diamond, and that is when I began working with them."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Just four years after starting her career in the competitive fashion industry, Lily Grimson has had two of her designs chosen for a major exhibition. All of her handbags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a bag; it is full of style, whether made from fine calfskin or heavy silk. The combination of elegance and care makes a Grimson bag special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. "Most women want hair that looks real and a style they can manage at home," he says. His goal is to make sure his clients look natural, as if they haven’t just come from a salon. However, this casual look comes at a price—£250 for the first appointment, and there is a three-month waiting list. Using his fame, Peter has created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so those who can’t visit his salon can style their hair at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and also works as a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain and top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to do something different. Her modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, "Flower arrangements are simpler these days. Keep them simple but strong, and don’t use too many leaves—they are too large. For wedding bouquets, remember: the flowers should be of the same type."

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It was created after a lot of research into what customers want and nearly two years of work to convert four large houses from the 18th century. This new hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests by name. For details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel treat returning guests in a special way, which is important for a five-star hotel. Although the system cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will save money over time. He praises its efficiency and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature that allows staff to record preferences.

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system that lets guests change the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a big part of the hotel’s guests, and MacCann estimates that about 65% of the business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a traditional business center into each bedroom. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. Extra cables have been installed to support new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be upgraded.

Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann says they have worked hard to make sure guests do not feel overwhelmed by technology. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, comfortable, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud’s restaurant in Dublin already had two Michelin stars when he decided to move his restaurant to the Merrion. Being part of the hotel has many benefits for him and the hotel. He has designed a new kitchen and improved parking facilities. For the hotel, having a successful restaurant means less financial risk. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is likely to succeed.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that goes from east to west show a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures. This is partly because of the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant."

Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants instead of painting the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they each change into different shapes. They open up and look amazing. When you first put them in a vase, they seem boring, but they change all the time."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers. I thought they looked like the fake ones sold in some flower shops. To me, the only real flowers were wild ones. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliff tops."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been hard lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her subjects, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**

Many trees in the Brackham area were damaged in the strong storms that March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these trees changed the look of the town center completely, which upset many of the local residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. He was a large and healthy man, but for the first time, he was seriously ill with bronchitis. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to convince him to see a doctor. He thought the police needed him too much, so he ignored her and tried to keep working. This made him forget things and made him short-tempered. It was only when his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor that he finally agreed to go. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, she took him to the pharmacy to get his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham could hardly believe it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged. He was relieved to hear it was not and pulled the sheets over his head. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics worked, and his temperature went down, that he realized the loss of the walnut tree had changed the living room forever. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It was expensive, but Pelham had no regrets about buying it. The garden had given them privacy. Now, though, the storm had changed how he saw things. Before, the view from the living room included the beautiful walnut tree. This tree had not made the room dark because there was also a window on the other wall, but it had created nice patterns of light and shadow that hid the old furniture they had brought from their previous home. Without the tree, the room felt too bright, showing the worn furniture in all its shabbiness. The view from the window was not pleasant. The tall house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its unattractive purple bricks and pipes. It had many upstairs windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams' every move.

"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. "That's what I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Text: Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers that could be in the surrounding hills and threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe and protected in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But in the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed for longer. Up there, the wind blew strongly. In our valley, we felt only sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by a series of dams built many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling up and getting close to a dangerous level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like Niagara Falls as the water rushed over the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the water rushed down to its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream looked furious beneath the bridge. It was much deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, angrily pushing against its banks. For three days, we prayed that it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our prayers were answered as the dam held and the water began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and appreciate the great power of the river. Thanks to the dam, we feel that our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

**Simplified Text:**

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews - novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and anything I was asked to do for the radio. That is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his staff. 

At first, he wanted a team of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need special knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to review from the artistic material Tom selected, and there would also be guests to make it more social. It felt like a dream at that time: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. I even thought a millionaire was helping me personally and pretending to hire me because I lacked self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I didn’t know where to look.

Tom's idea for a team of critics never really happened. It was a good idea, but we didn’t meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject area, so I chose film. Without Tom's initial support, we would not have developed the current system, where I write a longer weekly piece, usually about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t have liked the usual film critic's job, which involves reviewing every film that comes out. That routine would make me tired quickly. I would soon be sitting in my seat on a Monday morning, sighing, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" - a sigh often heard in screening rooms around the world.

The time I have allows me to expand my arguments or, in a boring week, to create something interesting from nothing. But what is my role in the public eye? I think people choose films based on the stars, the advertising, or the director. There is also loyalty to certain types of films. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to avoid a love story because of a review. So if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I have to be "right" about a movie. I also don’t think there should be a set number of "great" and "bad" films each year. All I need to do is present an argument. I’m not a judge, and I wouldn’t want to be one.

**Simplified Text:**

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." 

**Teenager with a Passion for Endurance**

WANTED: A sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. This is a chance to work with a potential Olympic champion. You should really enjoy distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (training in cold rivers is helpful), and distance cycling (enjoying 100km rides is a plus). You must be able to do all three activities without resting.

The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It has attracted large crowds who are fascinated (and sometimes shocked) by athletes who swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without stopping. It may be exciting for the audience, but why do triathletes push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, with great school results, give up so much for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that most athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you get cold. After the 40km bike ride, you have to run 10km, which feels long when you are tired. But it's great fun, and it's all worth it in the end," she says.

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior competing. It felt so easy that I waved at my teammates as I went around." Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the run." But she did not give up and is determined to keep trying. "Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I stop just once, I would want to stop again."

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I've just tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She gave it everything, but while most people stop when they realize they can't go further, she just kept going."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower in cycling. That's why I'm working very hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with £1,000 off") so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

But there is another cost. Her tough training sessions have made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times."

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events. She has done the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. Funny, isn't it?

**Text: The Collectors**

Amanda Roy writes about the things she collects and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults shares this interest. Collecting is a world of passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember this: if you do not truly love an object, do not collect it.

Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They were attracted to the shapes and colors of these pebbles, which were their first attempts to gather objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells just for their beauty.

I have been collecting all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I was sent to a school in a remote part of England, a cold and windy place surrounded by hills. When my parents visited, they took me to the local museum, which was full of objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these items. Surprisingly, I am not alone in my interest; one in three adults enjoys collecting too.

The reasons why people collect have become a popular topic. Some believe it is the only part of their lives where they have complete control. For me, it is simply something I enjoy. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like cups made from coconut shells and carved ivory beads. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned more than 4,000 paintings. However, you do not need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected many different items, like tulip bulbs and china cups, with great determination.

I remember the day I convinced another tulip collector to sell me a special one for my collection. I planted it and cared for it until, one year, it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Sadly, this collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall and saw the remains of my furniture and my collection. I was not sure which made me sadder.

I have always been interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet gives value to the items traded in markets. As small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. (Unfortunately, I threw them away, along with the toys inside.)

**Text: My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I am in charge of creating temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic beforehand and talk to important people to understand the main themes and goals. I also decide what objects and pictures should be shown. I must ensure that the public can understand the exhibition, which involves planning interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I also work with engineers and electricians to make sure the exhibition is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., the first thing I do is check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents need to be created for the students to learn the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, figuring out how to make the journeys. They find the most direct routes, using the correct one-way streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must take a different route because the road is closed. The next student must find another route, and I will give them a reason why they cannot go that way. This is to make them think.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. My job involves answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I usually work on the coast. I also collaborate with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the oceans. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the life beneath the water. This often changes their views, as it is very different from making decisions on a computer. I feel very lucky because conservation is my hobby, so I enjoy my job. However, I work for a charity, which means I always need to find more money. This makes it hard to achieve everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite varied. I need to ensure that our publishing program meets market needs and that we keep around 300 copies of the books we publish. We have very high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, and these need careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with my co-publishers. I work with a passionate team, which makes the job more enjoyable. The downside, like many jobs, is that there is too much administration to handle, which leaves less time for more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text: 'No Title'**

Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. One evening, he said, "How about this?" and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not a good experience because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were school friends, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We always think it is a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, naming the rooms we would stay in. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles repairs and decoration.

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling with his dark brown eyes sparkling, making us feel special, not just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. 

Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but didn’t play too long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. This is her second year as a chalet girl. Sarah, 24, is from West Sussex and works in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She thinks being a chalet girl is not a career but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower first, but she does not sleep. "It's not good if you do," she says. Dinner, which has three courses, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great - breakfast this morning was fun - but some weeks are not as good."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start at Bananas, then go to G Jay's and maybe Dick's T-Bar at the end of the night," she says. However, Sarah does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you really don’t want to cook breakfast with a headache."

On Sunday, work starts earlier than usual because breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for the new guests." If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them," she says.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes guests who need boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and sometimes she has a drink afterward, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

Text: 

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie loved to watch the workers shape and press each glove using steam-heated brass hands, which she called "pancake hands" because they looked flat and strange.

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He liked that she was interested in every detail. "They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I also worked there for six months when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," Rita said. 

"Well, you should visit a tannery if you want to write about leather. I can help you arrange that. They are old-fashioned places. The technology has improved, but they are not very different from what you would have seen hundreds of years ago. It's hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries in the world. They have found 6,000-year-old tanning tools in Turkey. The first clothing was made from animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject once you learn about it. My father is an expert on leather; you should talk to him. If you start a conversation about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers really love their work. 

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" 

"I can't say I have." 

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 

Seymour laughed. She made him smile. She was innocent and eager to learn. His daughter was much taller than Rita, but in other ways, Rita reminded him of Marie. He remembered how Marie would come home from school, full of what she had learned, with everything neatly written in her notebook. 

"I have an idea. We will take you through the whole process. Come on! We are going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Simplified Text:**

**Is it a tough job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, she has one small problem - she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is back on the ground, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has some boring paperwork to do, like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job. A chance meeting with a pop group’s manager led to her getting work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because golf is his passion. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings. His average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You are not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge, and try to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, and they made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are used by TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers themselves.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to taste food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge high prices? "For those who can afford it, it’s their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in my guaranteed income," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain’s most popular children's writers. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mostly wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It’s not easy; I have to work hard on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don’t wake up at dawn, though. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help with that."

Text: 'In the lumberyard by the lake, trees from the woods were turned into boards for building. There was an old two-story brick building, and outside, there were large piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles of dust covered the area down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, all the boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to jump too. 

Still laughing, he watched as they looked down from the roof, scared and unsure. One by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they all lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes. Finally, one of the boys said, "Come on up on the roof again and jump down." They were not very excited, but they went up to the roof again and started jumping off in a determined way until only Michael was left. The others were down below, smiling up at him and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" 

Michael wanted to jump down and join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning. He wondered why it hadn’t seemed like such a long drop the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He was trying to count to ten and then jump. When that didn’t work, he tried to take a deep breath and close his eyes. Soon, the boys began to laugh at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he didn’t move, they started to get up and walk away, still shouting. 

"Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called. But he stayed on the edge of the roof, staring sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and fell heavily into the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn’t jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home in time for dinner by now. If you won't come home, you might as well stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin and a little grey in her hair, always patient. She spoke with a serious tone, but Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the grinning faces below and hearing their laughter.'

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job turn to a careers adviser. First, you will write a short history of yourself and then take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggestions for different careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest organizations that provide career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that it wasn’t about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometric tests would show an accurate picture of me. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, but I was a bit disappointed to learn that I did poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are glad I never became a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean making a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts for help. "Losing my job was a great chance for me to step back and look at my career," says Donna. "I wanted to rethink my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But in the end, I had to think about the cost of retraining in design compared to my financial situation," she explains. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. "I decided to use my existing skills and move into something better suited to me than insurance. I am now a Public Relations officer. I believe I would have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me understand what I really wanted to do. I have sent several friends there, and they are all happy with the service."

Some people feel they would not have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services helped 26-year-old Juliet Greene make important decisions. "After working at a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, which showed I was interested in sciences," she says. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which I found very helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I listened carefully to the test results and decided I wanted to study geology. I plan to start a degree course in it later this year. I think the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I’m much happier now and more positive."

However, career advice doesn’t work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says, "I reached a point in my career where I didn’t know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either required a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself," she says. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Text: Fun at the Dentist's**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will see bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is because they are scared." To change this, he has tried to create a place where people feel safe. That is why he decided not to wear a white coat, which many people connect with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This idea is surprising for many people who think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past bad experiences." One of his new relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. The headsets are used during the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I check their teeth. Then the headset switches to a special camera that shows the patient a view of their mouth."

Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit. Another important detail is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome explains, "When people walk in, I want them to feel with all their senses that this is not like a regular dentist's office. Smell is very important. The typical dental smell can make people nervous if they are afraid of dentists." I also found the pleasant smell in the office very nice.

Although he is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, Jerome takes his work very seriously. The relaxation methods are important, but the quality of treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it is not painful at all. Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned there is that when you make it easier for the patient, it also makes it easier for you," he explains. He believes that his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a change towards less formality in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like a beautiful salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which comes from South America, is now a huge global business worth millions of pounds. During Easter, people in Britain spend over £230 million on chocolate. This is about eight percent of all chocolate sales for the year. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. 

Although chocolate production became large-scale in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, which is a spelling mistake from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans. 

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in the Aztec language, Nahuatl. In Aztec times, this chocolate drink was flavored with spices and used for ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to reach the rest of Europe. 

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in European capital cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid blocks of chocolate that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk solids to make milk chocolate. 

At the beginning of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. Then, Cadbury introduced the famous Dairy Milk bar, which started as Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a strong competitor to French brands. 

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain is stable at about four bars per week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are turned into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something different. 

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices from the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business because of this. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master of his craft. He still has many things he wants to try, like making paper and working with feathers. For now, he focuses on the skill he has enjoyed developing for the past ten years: creating delicate and unique objects from shells. 

"Tell me if I am boring you," he says as he shows me his work in his apartment. There is a fine line between being boring and being enthusiastic, but Cooke is definitely the latter. His charm and the beauty of his creations help with this. He points to a pair of shell-covered ornaments above a fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I have grown so used to them, and to me, they are adorable. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so people could see my work. They talked to a man who owns an art gallery."

The result was an exhibition in London, where 70 percent of the objects were sold. His second exhibition opened at the gallery yesterday. Considering the high prices of his pieces—around £2,000 for the ornaments—Cooke seems happy to give up some space above his fireplace. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has nothing to do with the prices and is open about them. He believes there is no one else in the world who makes work like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

"I do wish I had started this earlier," Cooke says, "because then I could have created even more wonderful things. Although I still have ideas and I am doing my best now, I am more limited physically than when I started." Still, the work he has created is very different from the common shell items found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led to boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers. Cooke has developed his own method and uses materials as he finds them. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for his flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker ("If it runs out, I don’t know what I will do!"), and washing-up liquid to clean the shells.

"I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he says about his working method. However, the attention to detail, color variations, and symmetry he achieves look far from accidental. Cooke's search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of damaging the world's beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people walking on them and breaking them much faster than I can collect them. The ones that are left are broken by the sea. I would never collect shells with living creatures in them or dive for them, but once their occupants have left, why shouldn’t I collect them?" 

This argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work, which often exceeds the beauty of the shells themselves.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to exciting places and appearing on magazine covers, she is likely studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more.

"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, that's fine," I replied. I was trying to convince myself that all the negative things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to my mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she thought going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, tall, and pretty girl. All models under 16 must bring an adult with them when they work, and her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was just a normal mum.

Kira seems a bit confused by her sudden fame, which makes sense since it was not planned. It was her older sister who suggested she enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should join," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When she found out she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to continue, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Kira now finds it hard to manage her two separate lives. However, her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. But some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I think too highly of myself." This must be difficult for Kira to handle, as she is not a self-important person. She says, "They think that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that has changed is that I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call her at any time and tell her she is needed for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll join them because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends understand. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even take their school-leaving exams. As I finish the interview with the girl who seems to have it all, I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the beauty that is likely to take her to the top. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Simplified Text:**

Father and son start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the hot lands of Africa in search of gold. The father and son team—one is an explorer and the other is a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool.

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to study. Since they first cleared away plants and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They have dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running out of money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a little deeper to where the gold is. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this looks doubtful, but we have a few people we can contact."

As news spread through the valleys about their dig, the excitement of gold began to attract the attention of local people as well as gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. "It would bring more people here if they are right," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if these two find gold, I hope millions of people do not come and dig at the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands of people worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots." They cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. Rachel adds, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a very pleasant journey."

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes that release black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.'" This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This smoke comes out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

Rachel recalls a frightening moment when she first dived with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. She heard a loud bang as shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they felt incredible relief—they were still alive!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them." Rachel studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD, and when she finally saw them in person, it was an amazing feeling.

Text: 'I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by foreign train schedules, money, and languages. "Never again," I said as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 

Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a regular bed; the movement rocks you to sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad and throwing away finished books. However, this carefree way of traveling is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be forgotten along with old books and socks. All you need is one of those tickets in your hand. 

A system that lets young people travel through many countries in one day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize how much we could do with this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too exciting, as there was always one more country to visit. And it didn’t cost us anything extra. 

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We planned our own schedule and focused only on the sights we could easily see. This was a chance to avoid guided tours and do something different. I was proud that in many places, all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, money, and music. 

The excitement of travel comes from arriving in a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrives, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different lifestyles can you really understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip may not let you discover new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is large, and Inter-Rail gives people a great chance to realize this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away.'

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you may be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck wearing clothes that are not suitable. Although airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, it is a fact that regular travelers will eventually be separated from their luggage. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially when your journey involves changing planes. 

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for luggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also extended to allow for luggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause flight delays. These issues can lead to problems with the baggage system. There is also the chance of human error, such as a destination label getting torn off. These problems can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 

For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to transfer between Terminal 1 (for Domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The risk of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. The United States also has issues; Miami airport is known for losing luggage when transatlantic passengers make quick connections to Latin America. 

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**Text: The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various yellows from the sunlight, creating a calm atmosphere like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, and it is gone in an instant, leaving a strong impression despite its small size.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He feels a deep connection to this little bird, but he cannot explain exactly why. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is said to be a moon goddess who turned into a bird. Another story tells how the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this story. Even though kingfishers have many shades of blue in their feathers, they do not have blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. Their beautiful colors and the fact that they can be watched from a distance make them fascinating. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just one meter away. However, it took him four more years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream where kingfishers lived. Unfortunately, school took away some of his time with the birds, and he missed classes, calling himself an "academic failure." But his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then worked as an assistant to the editor, and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked if she could attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant. Later, she was asked to help with another opera the next season. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous. I have always felt good about standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since that first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several more projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after trying twice before. Looking back, he is thankful for the timing: "If it had happened any earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and a period as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, Constantine finds it hard to shake off the "competition" label: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are now inviting me back. If this doesn't happen, my career could fall apart."

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial center until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
"Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me," says Roger Vignoles, 48. This career move is not so strange. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to get the performance I wanted. Fortunately, people respect my skills as a musician. I benefit from every experience I've had, both in musical style and in performing. Now, I will do whatever people ask me to learn what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor during one of his productions and told his agent about Wayne Marshall. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and did my best. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need advice from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to say what I want. If people see you are worried, it gets worse. I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are thinking about taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island would be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and nicer scenery. But the staff were very helpful, and we found it clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also great fun for younger children. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they found out they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides isn’t boring. It was very clean, and the staff were wonderful. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit of a coward, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it too easy, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we definitely felt that way. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the main attraction, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even worse! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. "My customers are friends," says CHRISTINE HOGAN, who runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were young, and I wanted a job I could do at home. I had worked with computers before I got married, so my husband suggested I start a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. But I was careful and always informed the bank manager if I might overspend. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. My business has stayed small. We rarely deliver work; customers from the area usually come to pick it up."

B. "I enjoy being independent," says MAGGY SASANOW, who designs greeting cards from home. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where there were no such jobs. So, I decided to start my own business and now I create a range of 50 greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. My business relies entirely on word of mouth; I don’t advertise at all. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I don’t share ideas with others anymore, but overall, there are more benefits than drawbacks."

C. "It has been hard at times," says DELIA TURNER, who makes curtains. "I started my business eight years ago when this type of work was growing. In two years, my earnings increased from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to have six full-time curtain-makers, but I had to let them go because of the economic decline, which was difficult since finding other jobs in this area is not easy. Now, I am back to making curtains at home with my husband’s help and using women who work from their homes. I have to be ready to lower my prices when needed and look for new opportunities."

D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons: it was cheaper than London, and I love the countryside. I enjoy being able to work when I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at unusual hours. The downside is that I need discipline to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. I had all my professional experience in London, so I felt very alone at first."

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home.
