I am very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with high-quality flour and eggs. Soon, I received requests from friends and family, and I started sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where everything is made. We have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don’t bake anymore; I manage the business side. My biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as we didn’t have a lot of money to start with."

**Text: Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are teachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He found out that the Welsh School of Instrument Making was nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John finally made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers that it turned out really well. John made another cello for him later, which Paul used until a few months ago. John has now retired from teaching and works full-time as a craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. He was very proud to sell one to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul began with the piano: "As soon as I could reach the keys, I played," he says. He later switched to the cello because he admired the cellist in his dad's music group. Although their parents encouraged them, Huw did not want to play the violin like Paul.

Huw, now 22, is becoming known as a pianist and composer. Paul has achieved a lot with the cello that his dad made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until last year, but now he has a cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music.

Paul jokes that his dad's cello will get better with age, just like his new one, which is already 304 years old. Soon, Paul will perform on television with his new cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he won't be able to watch it because he will be playing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks to one of the wardens who works for the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns.

Common sense is very important for a National Trust Warden, according to Gareth Roberts. "You also need to be good at dealing with people because you are always interacting with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies."

Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. "It helps that I still farm with my parents, so I can understand farmers and their problems. They can't trick me!" he says.

His farming background also means he can handle the physical work of the job, like putting up fences, planting trees, and building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. "When I was young, I used to pick flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and find old birds' nests. Recently, I thought about where I would find those flowers and nests now. I realize that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice."

Gareth explains that when he started, farmers and conservationists were often in conflict. Both sides wanted things done their way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. "We are at a point where we can bring them together," says Gareth.

Conservation is a big part of Gareth's job, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to make sure tasks are completed efficiently and without too much trouble. I enjoy seeing projects finished, even though I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork."

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially talking to the public. However, he admits, "I dislike the attitude of some people. They come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to those people can be frustrating!" But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense.

If you have plenty of common sense and like the idea of working outdoors, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day as she prepared for next month's World Championships. She had taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket car park. 

"Don't you get strange looks?" I asked her. She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's all." 

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships. I have a strict schedule to get fit for them." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Because we are playing at home, there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and give us more support. People expect us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra warns that the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train hard not to win," Kendra says. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We are all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. "As captain, I believe it is important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the rest of the team."

Kendra says, "From the very beginning, my netball career has been carefully planned. I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents help a child with great musical talent? It can be hard to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until they show frustration through difficult behavior. While most schools can help children who are good at academic subjects, musically talented children need special support that may not be available in regular schools, especially if music is not seen as important.

Children who are musically gifted, or whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools provide a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to develop their skills with the help of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, children spend about one third to one half of their day on music activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program that focuses on important subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small class sizes and a high number of teachers compared to students. Most children at these schools live there full-time, which means they spend their formative years with others who share their interests and goals.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; fees can be high (between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for boarders). However, each school tries to help parents of talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They emphasize that their main goal is to help children become well-rounded individuals.

It is clear that separating musically gifted children from a young age can cause stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, all specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help when needed. 

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met. For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education.

Children who are also academically gifted may do well in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a normal school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as opportunities to play in orchestras and chamber music groups. However, this option may not be possible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**Simplified Text:**

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that goes from east to west show a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures. This is partly because of the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant."

Susan likes to focus on detailed studies of individual plants instead of painting the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they keep changing."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked like fake ones sold in some shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem just as happy in her garden as they do in China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint at her back door, she has found it hard to work in the garden lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her subjects, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. This is her second year as a chalet girl. Sarah, 24, is from West Sussex and works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She thinks being a chalet girl is not a career but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful guests every week."

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower first, but she does not sleep. "It's not good if you do," she says. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great - breakfast this morning was fun - but some weeks are not as good."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start at Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe Dick's T-Bar at the end of the night," she says. But she never stays out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you really don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."

On Sunday, work starts earlier than usual, as breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for the new guests." If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them."

Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes guests who need boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and sometimes she chats with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper who spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear for my day at Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm and peaceful place, and here I was rushing around when I could be quietly spending time with an animal. Some members of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job is not very stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed at the thought that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I was petting one of the elephants, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening program Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My idea of gardening did not include hard work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to quit my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would faint while doing some tasks, but I was surprised that it didn’t bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very different from my usual male work environment. I feel my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew about from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drink a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes along the coast that goes to Italy. It takes you past some beautiful sea views. It doesn’t matter what the weather is like or what time of year it is; the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively because there is a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the amazing journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many train journeys over the years, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I ever saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding plans.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the train known as the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are young, but that’s not my case. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had taken care of. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Text: 'Want to Get Published?**

If you want to publish your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Where should I send it?" One of the first things they need to do is research their markets and learn about publishers while also improving their writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. 

No matter what type of writing you do, you need to know the markets you want to reach. There are several ways to do this, but the best way is to read as much as you can about your topic. Use your local library and visit local bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any time. 

As time goes on, you need to keep this knowledge updated because new publications are always appearing. Editors change jobs, and magazines change their focus. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so you need to give them what they want. 

At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. For example, if you think you want to write short love stories, the first thing you should do is find out which magazines publish love stories. This market is quite limited these days, so get as many recent copies as you can. Then, learn about the types of stories they are buying and who their readers are. These readers will expect different things from their magazines, and the editor wants to meet their needs. 

Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. However, it is unlikely that the work is ready for publication, so I try to give honest feedback while staying positive. The problem is that many new writers are too eager to send their work out before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This almost never happens. When you read about someone’s success, you usually find that they have been in publishing or journalism for years before their success. 

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will help your confidence and fluency grow. Don’t throw any of your work away; instead, try to improve it. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. 

Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you can’t find one, consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

**Text: No Title**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I expected. The usual clean and bright feeling of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers one by one. He looked well-off: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn’t mind talking to her. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, I’m going north, yes," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" 

"No, to New York, but I’ll be..." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said, and moved to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. "Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you going to Philadelphia?" When the woman said, "Wilmington," he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was thinking about the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn’t; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked very stressed now. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five—older than me. She looked like a school teacher. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Then could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away and looked at my left wrist (even though I didn’t own a watch). I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They were announcing my train now. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets on leashes. Then I heard the man talking. 

"My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries afterward, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn’t know what to do." The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where he was going with this. 

"So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would get someone here to bring her passport." I thought this was a strange story. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? "Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. He believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant. When John heard about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans. 

Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembers being sad when his mother went to work in a factory and he was left alone. Because of this, he wanted to make time for family. His wife took care of their children and managed the accounts while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become very confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined and would wake up even before John in the morning. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.

Gary was not very good at school, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes was in charge. He could cook over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would go into catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time to be successful. John told him, "If you want to achieve something, you need to do it by the age of 30. After that, it’s harder." 

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were beginners, Gary quickly chopped all his vegetables and sliced the meats. He even helped the other students. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you must work hard for it because nothing is given for free. Gary has recognized the opportunity he has and has taken full advantage of it. 

As parents, we talk to our children as they grow up, and if they remember even a little of what we say, we should be happy. John thinks that Gary must have listened sometimes because of the things he says and does.

**Text: Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal contacts. If you know someone who knows someone who is moving out, that can help. But if, like Jo, you have just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have any contacts. You might have to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin felt very new and unknown. She didn’t think about why she was going there. Everyone at school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to escape and experience life. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm because they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her while she answered an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice and that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.

There wasn’t a long line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. As Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."

"Oh," said Jo, continuing to climb. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, looked like a punk. Jo had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 

"I'm Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs: one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one with "Other." "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our love for dolphins has been supported by TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. 

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by law and cared for in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins around the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen only in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once often seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, including the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress from injuries on their skin.

It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also puts dolphins and porpoises at risk. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died after being caught in these nets.

Pollution in the sea can also harm dolphins. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. Female dolphins produce milk that can contain these poisons, which can harm their young. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It is one of the best ways to keep a good balance in your life, especially when everything around you feels chaotic. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.

Exercise helps improve your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. Exercise can also prevent muscle imbalances that may lead to injuries. It can quickly improve specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. Additionally, it benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these reasons many times, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It is also effective in managing stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you are not convinced yet, just think about it: exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you are unsure about what is best for you, it is a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is very important. No amount of exercise will improve your body shape if you do not have good posture. Good posture not only makes you look better, but it also gives you more energy and helps you avoid minor health problems. If you tend to slouch, try to imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head up. This can help you lift your chest and breathe better, while also making your body look slimmer.

Stretching your muscles is important because it improves flexibility and helps you move easily. It also helps you maintain good posture and prevents injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will have a more flexible and fit body. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, and it should be done slowly and carefully. 

The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it can be very hard to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost constant rain, causing many problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has created some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, the pair was already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.

Traveling filmmakers have been moving around the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. "We do have occasional arguments, but we get over them quickly," he said about his colleague. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and he believes they get along well because they both view the animals in a similar way. "When we are on the move, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we are staying in a more fixed camp. We set out at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be a bit stressful," says Newman. 

It can be a tough life, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often go off alone. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions, and after a while, she even greeted their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they began filming Arctic foxes together. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a good working relationship from the start because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is much better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, which was normal for her as she prepared for the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's all."

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to be as fit as possible." This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Because we are playing at home, there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and give us more support. People expect us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but it will still be exciting to play because they are a strong team. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra knows the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years Kendra has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train hard to lose," Kendra says. But after the game, everyone is friendly. 

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. "It is important that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."

Kendra says, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned." She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "Space is so limited that I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

"If there is a problem and we need to get to the top quickly, we can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site that was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I was scared was when I first dived with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She said, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I finally graduated, I felt very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "That morning, I saw a small hole in my jacket," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary did not get the job. One of her friends who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher's only comment was, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People often think that what is inside counts, but in an interview, you should try to present yourself in the best way possible." However, many people overlook the importance of having a professional image.

For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't matter."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well that she was offered the job immediately. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I showed too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't turn him down. As a result, he offered me a lower salary than I had hoped for. I believe I could have gotten more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it is a good idea to learn about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company's activities. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will show your interest in the company."

Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, I found that the City was no longer an exciting place to work. It became very tiring, and no one was having fun anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. I didn’t receive a very good pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel that has one of the top 20 restaurant in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed for me: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I realized I enjoyed it much more than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very helpful. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for money. But my wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a big change for us. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky that our friendships have lasted - many of them come to visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
After working for five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. "My job as a lawyer was enjoyable and I earned a lot of money, but the hours were terrible. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even more hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. Since it’s a fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a very organized schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I do miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am completely responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, I am the one who gets the blame. Of course, you care when you work for a company, but when your name is on the promotional material, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in financial markets since I was 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I never found the work satisfying. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life. That is the best part."

**Text: 'Dedicated to Their Sports'**

Four young sports stars talk about their lives.

**A Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun because there are great facilities for athletics and the nightlife is enjoyable too. However, I have to be very disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

**B Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are often at dawn. To succeed, I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I do enjoy sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it is worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a big win, I always celebrate, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice trip. The sacrifices are worth it because winning that championship allowed me to present a surfing series on TV. I guess I am a bit of a celebrity now.

**C Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When five guys are on a boat together, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and always celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish when we celebrate, but we do not seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than in our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it is great to come back and hang out with my friends who do different things. You cannot live and breathe the sport all the time; it is not healthy. I am known in the sailing world, but I am rarely recognized in public. I would not want to be a celebrity. I do receive many nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.

**D Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the support of the crowd. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. I am focused on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I feel stuck."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth are not convincing when compared to attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only learn about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their shopping requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I’m in a good mood, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their kids’ demands might attract enough extra customers to make up for it.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It was created after a lot of research into what customers want and nearly two years of work to convert four large houses from the 18th century. This new hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests by name. For details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel treat returning guests in a special way, which is important for a five-star hotel. Although the system cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will save money over time. He praises its efficiency and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature that allows staff to record preferences.

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system that lets guests change the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a big part of the hotel’s guests, and MacCann estimates that about 65% of the business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has brought the traditional business center into the guest rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. Extra cables have been installed to support new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be upgraded.

Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann says they have worked hard to make sure guests do not feel overwhelmed by technology. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, comfortable, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud’s restaurant in Dublin already had two Michelin stars when he decided to move his restaurant to the Merrion. Being part of the hotel has many benefits for him and the hotel. He has designed a new kitchen and improved the facilities. The hotel can now offer a popular restaurant without financial risks. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is likely to succeed.

**Simplified Text:**

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:**  
"I think excitement gives me energy. I need to be doing something challenging. When I learn new things, I feel very energized. I also get energy from rhythm; right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is amazing and makes me feel alive. If I'm bored, I feel tired and think life is dull. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all. I love my job, so it doesn't feel like a burden. If you enjoy what you do, you won't feel too low, even if you're tired. I need enough sleep, and when I get it, I feel great. When I only get six hours of sleep, I feel a bit off. I know exercise gives me energy, but sometimes it's hard to find the motivation. I go to a yoga class once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to eat something then."

"I don't eat very healthily for energy; I think my natural enthusiasm and positive attitude help. I can't stand negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and make the most of every moment. I rush to get them developed because I can't wait to see them. I've also started writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

I didn't know it was private.' I like this because it feels playful."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has a history that goes back thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the upper classes in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish and formal, but at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style that made skating very popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both beautiful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are very important, and speed comes with practice. The way you position your body is key to maintaining balance. Your legs should be slightly bent, and your knees should be relaxed to keep your weight centered. In this position, your body leans a little forward. Relaxation is crucial for skating, more than in many other sports. 

To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. While pushing forward with your back foot, make a small movement with your other foot. It’s not too hard! If you keep practicing, you can gradually make longer movements as you get better. Learning how to fall is one of the first skills every skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed, which helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.

Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer good guidance, so you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.

If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, it is important to practice a regular exercise program. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, and shoulders, especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits your heart and lungs and strengthens your body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Bills**

If there is one thing that can make you cry with happiness, it is seeing a talented child receive a medal. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I just keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."

B. **Annika's mother**: "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I have seen some parents push their children, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy, and she has to want to do it herself. People often say that we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence from her success."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at the age of ten and has won the British National Championship. "It’s a good thing my parents love show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love show-jumping; it is exciting and fun. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I am very determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother**: "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she had found her passion. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living area of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is completely happy on a horse and knows what she is doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is one of the best feelings."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being arrogant; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother**: "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. Of course, I am happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

**Simplified Text:**

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher that he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" The teacher was joking because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors were. We are losing the effects of many years of poor diet, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are starting to reach our true potential. We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, farming began, which changed everything. Most of the world's green areas have been taken over by farms, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health. 

Over the years, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed. **Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people do not understand them. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder who they are. 

Some people think that studio audiences are not very important. I have heard that even people who work in television do not think highly of them. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through long hours of waiting just to watch what they can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on television. I did not believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said, "I came for a chance to be on TV." Another reason people go is that they are curious about how shows are made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket."

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when told. This may be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We believe a good show does not need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live television. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors; I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.
