**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are 'animal people' who love all kinds of creatures. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to say she had found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked excitedly. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for such visitors, just long enough to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly put a pot on to boil when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The problem involved Domino the cat and Bianca, the white mouse I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the children waving their arms.

I jumped into the chaos and tripped over something, landing on the floor. As I thought about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It had escaped and was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat were jumping around in a loud, chaotic scene. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over.

I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and pulled the small, wet, and surprisingly unharmed mouse from his jaws. This same mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged by my success with the cat, I looked at the snake. It seemed strong and calm. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without a flute. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked suspicious. I carefully placed my hands under the snake and stood up, walking to the end of the garden. I pointed the snake towards a tree, hoping it would find a good home.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to bite me, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, making itself comfortable. We stood there in the fading light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific comment: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

I had the children gather at the snake's tail and gently encourage it to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Text: 'Write to Me!**

In our fast world of phones, faxes, and computers, the old art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by any other way of communicating. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and pleasure in reading its contents.

Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back to me. Sometimes my father wrote, and I loved receiving his long, funny letters. Most of the letters from home shared everyday news about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch through letters. Instead of hurting our relationships, writing letters seemed to make them stronger. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than by talking.

I enjoy the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a whole year’s worth of news! I especially love receiving letters in airmail envelopes with beautiful stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from a friend I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There is also a lady in France who writes to me. If we hadn’t started talking in a restaurant after a holiday, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her (she doesn’t speak English), and we have visited each other’s homes.

My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our friendship lasted so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it on the front page!

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.'

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain is thought to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include pictures of cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and makes the artwork less clear. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people think they can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to make them look clearer," he said. "The drawings are already polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they just rub and scrape them."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He says that if this does not happen, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says, "Henry de Lumley's plan is very strict, and while it may be effective, it will also upset local people." He adds that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't perfect. Our department believes the best solution is to let people visit the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I would prefer that everyone could see it, but the main problem is money. We do not have enough funds to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee, as there seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—since tourists can now avoid the long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't happen because there is no money," she said. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I feel stuck."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth are not convincing when compared to attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their shopping requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers.

**Text: Climbing Walls**

In the past, climbers went to the mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches closely as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common: The Wall. The ability to have these events is thanks to new technology that is developing quickly.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid getting bored.

Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls using special bricks that climbers could hold onto. One of the first climbing walls was built by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Many similar climbing walls were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s, but they had some problems. These walls could only be straight up and down, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French manufacturers also started to make climbing panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for making overhanging walls without a lot of construction, but steel frames could be built anywhere. This system of interchangeable holds gave climbers many new options to try.

**Text: 'So You Want to Be an Actor'**

If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably mention that it is a risky career. Acting is indeed risky because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might say you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. Ultimately, it is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own path and dreams.

There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee you will succeed in the profession. Success often depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes good rewards.

Many people ask what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination, which is hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. 

Where does the desire to act come from? It can be hard to explain why you want to act. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. 

If you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they might not have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they do not take their success for granted. They understand that their fame can be temporary. 

Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid talking about their chances of success. They find ways to cope with the stress of competing for roles and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected. 

From the moment you start auditioning, you are saying that you are available and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, your success depends on how much you care about acting, because if you don’t care, others may not care about you either.

**Food for All**

We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, and she loves exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a key reference for modern cooks. It offers simple but expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes that are not boring. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

To go along with his first TV series, "Blanc Mange," he has written a book with the same name. He thinks it is possible to make something tasty in the same time it takes to order a pizza. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel has written over 200 recipes from around the world in his fun and enjoyable style. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer exciting. It became very tiring, and no one was having fun anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel that has one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed for me: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very helpful. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a big change for us. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky that our friendships have lasted, and many of them come to visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot of money, but the hours were terrible. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. Since my business is related to fashion, I have to keep up with collections and next year’s styles, so there is always a lot to do. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am completely responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one who gets the blame. Of course, you care when you work for a company, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in finance since I was 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I never found the work satisfying. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life. That is the best part."

**Text: A Winning Game**

Two brothers are discovering that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played the game and, as Dave says, "had the best time ever." Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico, but they did not forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, which he made from old wooden crates. They continued to play regularly. When visitors came by, they were often curious because the game was unknown in the southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave noticed how cracked and worn the old pichenotte board had become and decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, and then a friend wanted another. To see how much interest there was, one night the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But then they'd sit down, and soon you couldn't get them up from the table!" When people asked about the game's origins, Dave did some research. He found that the roots of the game were probably in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This was adapted into a game called 'squails' played in pubs in Britain. A century ago, British people who moved to Canada brought the game with them. Pichenotte is the name of the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec.

Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player gets 12 pieces or 'pucks.' These are flicked across a wheel-like board using the middle or index finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points, respectively. Eight small posts act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

When they saw how popular the game was at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money changed hands, and the game's popularity grew. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly. Eventually, they decided to start the pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and began making boards. They have produced more than 450 boards so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12 kg and is 1 cm thick. As Norm explains, "They're very durable, as they have to withstand a lot of use." They are available for $595 each on the brothers' website.

Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage to create pichenotte stars. However, the day may come when the brothers' garage will hold a luxury Mercedes instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of waste land, flat and covered with brambles. For many years, it was seen as useless land. The careful planning and hard work of one man, with the support of his wife, changed this land into the beautiful place you see today. 

During the building of the village, many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat area into the shaped landscape you see now. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of hard work was also done by hand. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were brought in to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. 

In creating the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These plants had to be chosen carefully for the area. Only plants that could survive the salty air near the sea were used. They also had to withstand strong winter winds in this exposed location. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand. 

The whole village was designed by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by hand over nine years after the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to resist all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how different materials would last through changing weather. But soon, he became an expert himself. 

You will notice that a consistent scale has been followed, and great attention has been given to even the smallest details of the models. This was achieved through patience and the development of special building techniques. The Model Village has become a very popular attraction and is known for its high quality and maintenance. The methods used to create these realistic models have been used in other model villages in England and have even been included in some college courses on modeling. 

All the model buildings you will see in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. 

As you walk around the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition to the village. We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models; even a small mistake can lead to hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead. 

To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these buttons to make the models move. At the end of your visit, we welcome any comments you may have. New models are always being planned, and your ideas will help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if there are any models that you think need improvement. We are always replacing and updating the models, and we need your feedback on which ones need attention. 

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!

**Simplified Text:**

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do pose for paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. Very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle these issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel—a place where people expect privacy—she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. The PCC should also look into a recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on this and other unfair attacks? 

This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other newspapers and shown on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to hide behind trees to take pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be several problems. How would it decide whether to start an investigation? Should it talk to the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still did not want to do anything, should the PCC still proceed? Celebrities and royals might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and they could be upset if it wasn’t. 

The role of the PCC is very big. How could it realistically monitor all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story that they want to keep from the press, and they know that complaining could make that story public. In other words, even the PCC might become a problem for them. 

One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he complain later when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, saying they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Text: 

Many college graduates receive advice about starting their first job. This article focuses on what to consider when moving to a second job. We are not talking about those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they don’t like within a few weeks. Instead, we will discuss how to take a real step in your career. You should choose a job that matches your goals now that you have gained some experience and skills.

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to more responsibility, or explore a different field. Whatever you choose, be careful in selecting your second job. You should aim to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next position. It should show that you have planned your career seriously. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and give you more responsibilities.

If you feel the urge to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can work temporarily when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because they were very supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no chance for promotion. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really grown. From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same as when I started, but my responsibilities have changed. I now handle most of the correspondence and budgets, and I deal with questions from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and also gives me specific projects and events to organize."

**Text: 'What is the Secret of Confident People?'**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but most will say it is a skill they learned because they needed to. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I was sure I wouldn't do well, but I surprised myself and did great. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on the first day of my class, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school was a turning point in my life that helped me in many other areas.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey started four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became a bit too aggressive. I thought that was what being confident meant, but I learned that to be confident, you need to believe in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I often talk to myself to push those fears away.

**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but the calmer I seem, the more scared I actually am. I had to learn to look confident because it is very important in TV. Interviewing people has shown me that most of us feel nervous in important situations, and we feel better when we talk to someone friendly. The best advice I got was from my mother when I was a teenager worrying about my clothes. She said, 'Who is looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about themselves.' I remember that often. I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous when I took my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I would never be that scared again, and I haven't been.

**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked in the restaurant, but I know that not everyone will like me. I don’t let that bother me. You need to like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others want. My company offers many training courses, and taking those has helped my self-esteem. The company also encourages us to set realistic goals. It helps a lot to see that you are achieving something, rather than trying to do everything at once and ending up with nothing.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and would sit in meetings, often disagreeing but too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I first worked in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with fear. I told myself, 'Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I also found it helpful to write down a few points to refer to, like having a comfort blanket! I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is telling yourself again and again, 'Nothing is impossible.'

**Text: Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional - if the line breaks, finders keepers... and anyway, I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat down in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan and looked at Malaysia's biggest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a line of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the air like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each competitor had entered four different designs, which would be judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying ability. 

"Flying kites isn't so hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how to do it." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he asked me to come back the next day to start rebuilding his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains covered with lush rainforest. 

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that pointed up a path into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started, it would have been good to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tent kitchen and a few bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin mattress. 

The night was completely dark, filled with different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a fantastic view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. 

No one is a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their questions were friendly. Kelantan might be famous for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

**Text: What Kind of Shopper Are You?**

We all go shopping, whether we like it or not. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know what type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.

A. **Melanie, 22, dancer**  
"I love shopping! When I have money, I go out and enjoy it. I can't resist sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We are both addicted to shopping!"

B. **Brenda, 40, office manager**  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but it’s hard because we all like different things. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I really did."

C. **Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
"I only shop for what I need. I dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and I don’t settle for anything else. Shopping is tiring for me."

D. **Anita, 35, TV producer**  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to shop quickly. However, I do have some clothes in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes."

E. **Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
"I really don’t enjoy shopping. I dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or get help. The shops are too noisy and messy, which makes it stressful. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."

F. **Lisa, 22, actress**  
"I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have something specific in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it."

G. **Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
"I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much money."

H. **Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
"I love shopping, but I prefer to go on quiet days, never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper; I have an idea of what I want and I don’t rush into buying things. I check other shops to find better deals, which takes a long time."

I. **Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
"I don’t like shopping much, maybe because I work in the city center and the shops don’t excite me anymore. When I have to shop, I go but don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind making mistakes rather than spending a lot of time in shops."

**NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE**

The Open University offers degrees just like other universities. However, you can study without leaving your job. This can also help you explore many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the exciting experience of learning new things. You will meet many different people. Your degree may also help you find new job opportunities. 

At the Open University, you do not attend lectures in person. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. There are exams to take, just like at any university. 

If you want to learn more, just fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets can be picked up at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and asked different questions about them. The quiz sheets will be available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery now has a beautiful still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for a painting like this to have two dates because the artist waited for certain flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was kindly given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is now on display in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this period: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work, and on 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will speak about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and showcase the collection of important European art from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for their children to have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to make food for themselves when they leave home."

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun hobby that can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from family, and letters from pen pals. 

When you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways: 

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. If you prefer, we can send you individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too! A two-year membership costs just £5. If a group of friends joins together, you can get a discount. This is great value for money! 

When you join, the Club will send you a Starter Pack for free. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also receive a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to add to your collection and useful addresses of shops that sell stamps. 

Every two months, you will get a copy of the club magazine, which has competitions and quizzes. You can also exchange stamps with members from around the world. 

Why not start an adventure that will give you years of enjoyment? You will spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unique ones that are waiting to be found. 

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun of stamp collecting! To join, just fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent to you within 28 days after we receive your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are like a gram or a kilometre. The main difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, traded the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a simple exchange between two people, each with something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of money, called 'currencies', to make trading easier. Eventually, different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

**Text: Write a Winning Story!**

You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky winners will receive a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges include Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a television reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you:

1. **Write About What You Know**: This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most stories were about love, family, and problems with friends. Try to make ordinary situations interesting so that people want to read them.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: Make sure your descriptions are accurate. If you are not sure about something, do not write about it.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a good story. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the ending.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using good words to describe them.

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and printed on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories sent by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. 

You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country. This is a new rule based on popular request. Your story must not have been published in any form, such as on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. 

Your entry fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Please make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist known in history. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that his daughter received the best education possible. This was rare because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. Although we do not have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented some scientific tools to help with her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone involved in it was in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is twelve kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is near the A1 main road. There is also a two-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to the peaceful area of Yarwell, which is the current western end of the line.  
**Fares:** Adult £10.00, Child £5.00, Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It is a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, and a nature reserve, as well as a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from many parts of Europe. This includes famous trains like the De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these trains all year round, whether or not the Nene Valley Railway is running. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. A good example is the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups to visit and for teachers to set projects. The work can be done while students are there or in the classroom. A special educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. A month’s notice is needed for booking. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. For more information, call 01780 784444.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a great place for special family events or company visits. It can provide a unique setting for an interesting afternoon or evening. Special programs can be arranged to include food, drinks, entertainment, and more. For more information, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Text: Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. 

Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food available.

Text: 'Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and has just won the title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she has drawn clothes and created designs. She never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After finishing university, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to industry events but could not afford the designer clothes she liked. So, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her clothes, they asked her to make some for them too. She then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs. They were very popular, and nothing was returned. This gave her the confidence to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own women's clothing brand. Kal's parents were not upset about her career change and said they would support her, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Her business has grown a lot, and she knows she is very lucky. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.''

**SUNNINGDALE HOTEL**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service to guests from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here. The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the center of town, and buses to many other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue sign that says "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 comfortable, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking available in the hotel driveway. Daily newspapers are provided for free, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests who stay for a long time must pay for their rooms weekly in advance, and they need to give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. For those studying or working late, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or by calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires of any kind (for cooking or heating) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests are advised to take a taxi to the hotel if they arrive by train, as we are a bit far from the main railway station.

**Text: Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and found it hard to make friends, but he loved being in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became very successful and was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner had also been looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.'

**Text: The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across the Australian continent, from the warm northern coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late. 

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. However, there were often floods on the line, making it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished a few months before my journey. The railway was built for speeds of up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia via Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent.

It is not every day that a transcontinental railway is completed, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south railway. As I waited to board the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the journey. Many of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners who were particularly eager to get on the train. 

Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan waited for four hours. Some passengers got off and took a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group just walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. 

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train did not meet all the promises in the advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Text: Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Each year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. 

"It was February, my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is six hundred metres high, probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You would have trouble on Ben Nevis without them because the snow can be very hard, like ice. 

Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. Although the weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. 

The path quickly went up, and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb. 

After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the route to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a metre and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. 

After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. However, we were not so lucky because a mist had come down. 

Getting back down to camp can be just as hard as going up. You need to read a map well; a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top."

**Text: Anna's New School**

It has been a very exciting week because we have just moved into our new school building! It is an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like in our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The school took months to build, and we watched it being built. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it also meant that some nice open space was lost. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop working because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are very big—much bigger than the old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town when they have meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and large changing rooms that we are looking forward to using when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, one of the first things you notice is that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from everyone inside—the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed so well that it keeps all the heat inside. It also keeps the sound inside, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders put it there after finishing the roof because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for the lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures that we plan to put on the website.

Even though we are already using the school building, some parts are still being added. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we still have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will all learn much faster now that we are in it!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and getting new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:** You just need to send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:** As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' book list, up to the value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money compared to the publishers' prices. You can also tick a box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift chosen from our book list by our staff. You can order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you join:** As a member, you will enjoy savings of 30% to 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, which will keep you updated on the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:** All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want to take. In each monthly magazine, our experienced staff choose a Club Choice book, which is a fiction or reference title they think is worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just let us know on the form. We will send the book if we do not hear from you.

So, return your application form today, but hurry - this is a special offer! To apply, just fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope. Before you know it, your books will arrive. Please do not send any money now; we will send you your bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can either return the books or send your payment.

**Text: No Title**

A month ago, I had no idea that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place where we stayed was not great, but we had everything we needed (beds, blankets, food), and we were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we were not sure how. Half of us spent the morning caving while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. 

A young man asked me what was wrong, and I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. 

I got my handbag back, and amazingly, everything inside was untouched. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are some of the most frightening animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they can see very well and can feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. 

Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they hardly sleep at all. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who need to handle sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting creatures.
