Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. On my first day of ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came over to ask me questions, all in Russian. I tried to speak a little Russian, and they started talking to me in English, so we could understand each other. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I can understand my teachers.

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late one night to talk to her because I felt lonely. The classes in Russia are much harder than those in my ballet school in England, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This makes me confident that I can meet the school’s high standards.

In the evenings, I watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish. Now that I have settled in, I feel at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Right now, we are getting ready for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice by themselves. By the end of the 1980s, people began to see the dark and cold winter as a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors to the area. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous around the world.

As soon as winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. When one part is finished, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is completed in December, and each week after that, a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully finished. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural materials from winter, the finishing date can change depending on the weather.

In spring, as the weather gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5°C to -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothes like warm overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks. They should choose shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Text: Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening.

A police officer who was called to the shop said: "The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The shop quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space for them. Another problem was that there was a long line of cars trying to get to the parking lot. I couldn't believe that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the shop. This blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: "I waited in line for three hours, and I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in Britain.

**Society Magazines**

We produce several excellent magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine features short stories by some of Britain's best writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, includes interviews with writers and has information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing community. You can find articles from recent issues on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We run the National Short Story Competition, the largest competition of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and short stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members pay £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a contract to publish their own collection of short stories.

**Education**

For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and helping them build confidence in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place with freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is perfect for looking through the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or over can join. If you want to become a member of The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

**Text: Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on just one breath of air. In 2003, she made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean while holding her breath and then swim back up without help. A year earlier, she had dived deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man.

A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive from different depths. After some serious accidents involving other divers, some people say free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya disagrees. She believes that safety is the most important thing, followed by training. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya keeps the same training schedule no matter what she is preparing for. Two-thirds of her training is done at the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking to build her fitness.

When she practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, taking a rest day between each dive. It is important for her not to get tired, as that could ruin her preparation. When Tanya is not training for an event, she often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects and films.

Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she swam whenever she could and spent long afternoons exploring rock pools to watch sea life. Tanya says her life today feels like living her childhood dreams. Because she is well-known in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. Looking to the future, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to keep breaking her own world records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and is eager to continue in the sport for many more years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and advanced computer programs are making cartoons exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, many in the cinema world thought cartoons were only for children. However, soon after, a few directors had original ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy together. Not every cartoon film was successful, though. For example, *The Black Cauldron* failed because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role. "I never expected to spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted at school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me to say there were plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. She was surprised at first, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the role. The outdoor filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. Once I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to write the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel so lucky. After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I’m not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles but haven’t received any offers yet. I don’t know how I managed everything because I had a busy social life too. When filming finished, I didn’t know what to do. I have since appeared in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I’m going to Greece for the summer with friends."

**Text: No Title**

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is in this book. I believe that we, as a company, have important ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our values. 

This is not a typical business book, and it is not just about my life. The main message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can help others. In business, as in life, I want to enjoy what I do, feel a sense of family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. 

Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' along the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can carry 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private showers and toilets. On board, there is air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** Depart in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Your guide will meet you when you arrive and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After sightseeing in Oporto in the morning, you will return to the ship and leave for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, where port wine is made. At dinner, you can try delicious local food and drink.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that used to be a palace. The museum has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Then, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return journey to Tua will be by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a beautiful ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** There will be a trip to Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then heading down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with enough time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. 

In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey so much that they used it as payment. Today, honey is produced and eaten all over the world. Research shows that honey can help reduce tiredness and improve athletic performance. Honey is not just food; it can also be used for sore throats and is found in many skin and hair-care products.

**Text: Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain. It has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it an important center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It continued to grow for the next 300 years, becoming wealthy and famous for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days in a year. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and its success as a modern commercial center (it is the largest center for insurance services outside London), Norwich now offers many entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and various arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', which wears green and yellow.

One of the city's new attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the middle of their city while builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a city center park on the roof of the Mall, complete with beautiful water pools and hundreds of trees. The local people are happy that the old open market still exists in the heart of the city, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the best of the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, becomes filled with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, an annual event that lasts for nine days. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a parking lot in the center of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from more than one-third of the countries in the world are expected to participate.

**What to See**

The pilots communicate with each other using radios, and they all light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This event is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great chance to take amazing photographs. To see the "glows," you should arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am, as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, with some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, as well as popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will enjoy it too. 

In the afternoon, you can even take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies that offer rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a great view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates perfect conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are important. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you use film instead of a digital camera, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and night photos.

**The Eden Project**

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist attractions. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many products we use every day come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a large waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone in the near future.

Text: 'No Title Some people have said they do not like this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I do not understand why. 500 pages of original writing for £6.99 is quite amazing, right? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less famous writers mostly wrote about food. I recommend you do not read Jane Harris's Those Nails right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes! There is also great work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You will find pieces from novels that are still being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers, and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about herself. This is an exceptional collection, and I am excited to see what next year's collection will include.'

**Text:**

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are discovering the world." Margaret, who lives in London, usually teaches children who are three or four years old, but she has also accepted some eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old friends.

Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts one hour, every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her each week. Parents must also attend the classes because it is important for them to be involved in the lessons.

From the very first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how they play and how they read music. Margaret says that her teaching method is not meant to create great violinists. She often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

**Text: Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined as the new drummer. 

From the first song on the CD, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans. Either of them could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford gets a chance to show how good he is, reaching each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs for the album before he had problems with his throat. This has caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who has bought tickets does not need to worry, as all the concerts will be rescheduled as soon as Rob has recovered.)

On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the dance tracks that will keep you moving. However, I felt that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

**Text: San Francisco**

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbor, it was discovered by land, not by sea. 

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. 

Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the old prison.

**SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of that time, such as diseases, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about his own life, including his mistakes—like often sleeping during church or looking at pretty girls. He describes his home life, including a fight with his wife and how they made up, as well as his worries about her health. Besides reading, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs—he was a Member of Parliament and the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not think much about whether shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also common, depending on current fashion trends. 

It was only about one hundred and fifty years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now most shoes are made by machines in large factories, although some shoemakers still use traditional methods. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry produce many more shoes at lower prices for more people.

**Text: No Title**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women get into running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident enough to start. I decided to create a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with how some race organizers think. They often say there are not enough women in the sport, but they also use this as a reason not to provide separate changing rooms.

I put up posters, and 40 women of all ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn’t think about having fun, chatting, and smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about diet and staying fit from other runners. I wanted to support women's running, and it has been a joy to see their progress—almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people came to Alaska hoping to get rich. New towns were built quickly, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. 

In the summer, supplies could be delivered by boat, but in the winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it hard to reach the towns. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They delivered mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took a team of dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could sleep and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced dog teams as the main way to transport goods. However, in 1925, the dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the closest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were new, and no one was sure if they could fly in the cold weather. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away at that time. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead.

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He trusted his dog Togo to find the way through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be a great guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further and saved the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Text: Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of the most unusual hotels in Europe. In this hotel, you eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even have a wedding there. The bar is made of ice too, so it is not a good idea to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to keep warm. They can also get outdoor clothes if needed. The hotel lasts for only six months because it melts in summer, and every winter it is rebuilt. It takes 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow to create the hotel.

**Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was playing football as the only girl on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized that she was very fast. 

"He talked to me about athletics. I didn’t understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs really hurt." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help their family. They agreed to let him take her away to train. 

In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and mostly to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, especially from the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of visitors have enjoyed it. You must wear special covers over your shoes to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest but are also found a few hundred miles from the center in the southern areas. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are still very beautiful. There are many roads that go through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your journey from Vancouver, which is one of the most attractive cities in Canada. This city is located by the water and near the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the ride is still an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will see some of the best views at night.

**Text: ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. The first big zoo was opened by the rulers of China and was called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the early days, animals were trained to perform for visitors, but this is no longer done. Now, the main purpose of zoos is to let people see animals behaving naturally.

Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with zoos. Supporters say that zoos help us learn about the natural world and allow us to see wild animals up close. They believe these experiences would not be possible without zoos.

On the other hand, some people do not support zoos. They think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals may live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like my band to brightly-colored T-shirts. We didn’t look like professional adult bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of our playing was amazing, especially since we are all so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played!  

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets accepted—only about half of the students. However, anyone who wants to play can go to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it’s because pop music isn’t challenging enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, as you play on stage like great jazz performers did before you. My school is lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn’t get far with our music!

**Text: Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it does not rain often. When it does rain, the city's water pipes cannot handle the sudden floods, and the streets become like rivers. Many winters have been dry recently, so when it finally rains, the local people are very happy. 

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain; instead, they get water from a system of underground channels that were built in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year round. Places that are mostly dry but receive water this way are called oases.

Further south of Marrakesh is Skoura. In Skoura, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels, and people use these squares to grow food. The Atlas Mountains, which are covered in snow during winter, create a beautiful view.

**Text: Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis, 13, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in the circus. They both found jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and return home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. 

"I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." 

"People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." 

And what about the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to national and local newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet other members and join projects. We plan to open more centers soon. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: "I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to do stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee on a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share their skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who go with them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. The exact flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to a different date if needed.

**Questions**

Here are answers to some common questions about our flights.

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will give talks about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that shows a view from the cockpit on the video system, from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will need to move to the seat shown on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting places to give everyone a good view from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain checks the satellite images of the clouds and chooses the direction that offers the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! All cameras are welcome. We even have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for their children to have fun and learn how to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to make food for themselves when they leave home."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill. Ice might be hidden under melting snow, which can cause you to lose control of your car. A car coming towards you might slide across the road unexpectedly.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you are driving with a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to pay attention to what could happen. The more ice there is, the further down the road you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London to study law, but instead went to art school. He found the traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art, and he became interested in early Italian artists, which can be seen in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian fields and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This led him to layer colors from light to dark, but he admits he is never sure what the final result will be. He says, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top."

Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it seem easy. "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what you put the colors next to." Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting because he feels that if he did, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he prefers to paint people who do not ask to see their pictures while he is working. "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since moving to London years ago, he has not felt part of the Scottish art scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

**Text: 'Rock Band'**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it'll keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "All right, but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the beginning. Because drums are hard to move, Ben's band members started coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music may sound a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill; after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager. They do play regularly in local clubs for young people. 

Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but this hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is certain: Ben was right; it has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

**Text: Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. It offers young people important experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to study for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from all over the world, study in the morning. In the afternoon, they participate in useful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different backgrounds and countries. Since few can pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, there are grants available. About a quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they receive government support.

"I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don’t like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn’t believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In summary, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education using methods that really work.

**Text: Being an Older Student**

At 32 years old, I have just completed my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job did not challenge me. I became more and more unhappy thinking that I was stuck in that job. I envied the students at the local university, who seemed happy, carefree, and excited about their future. I wanted to be part of that.

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the professors because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I am grateful for this chance to study because I understand that having a qualification is important for getting a good job.

Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. I also enjoy the usual student benefits, like long holidays and discounts for theaters and cinemas. I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age has been a smart decision.

**Text: Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong but light steel, he created affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he produced the first Ford Model 'T', which sold for $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 

'Dear Sir, 

I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like to get more information. How much does a course cost? How long is each course and when does the next course start? 

Yours, 
Maria Gonzalez 

Dear Ms. Gonzalez, 

Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This is a 6-week course and it costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another 10-week course for £200. I hope this information helps. 

Yours, 
David May'

**Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS'**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very difficult. "You must carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often ask her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!

Text: 'Dear Mike, I am sorry you could not come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and stayed in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party; the best I have ever had! Many of my friends were there and they gave me nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

**Text: CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds won't know what to do in autumn." 

Bill had a small plane, and he decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When the cold weather came in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him the whole way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home.

This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back, but they did not arrive. So, he flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not find them. When he got back home, Bill was surprised to see the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and some glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon made double the £500 her aunt gave her.

At first, her parents did not want Esther to spend her time making jam. They thought she should study instead and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther did not listen to them. She continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked.

After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were very happy with her. She made all kinds of food and sold it to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to help her.

Text: 

'Dear Jacqueline, 

Would you like to go to the cinema with me after school today? We can see Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? 

Love, 
Isabella 

Dear Isabella, 

I am very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has some work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you invite Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. 

Love, 
Jacqueline'

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them cool.

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters from the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But since it was summer and hot, people did not want to buy sweaters. Instead, she made socks. Everyone loved the socks because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began. 

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers. So, she started sending the wool to a factory, where machines now make all the socks. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different types of socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers from all over the world.

Text: 

'28 Long Road  
Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,  

I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made many new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me when I make mistakes. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.  

Best wishes,  
Maria'

**Text: 'BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON'**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of house burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people have left home and forgotten to close a door or a window. 

Inspector Saunders explained that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. However, winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark, and they can’t be seen easily. Many houses are empty during this time because people are often still at work. 

Inspector Saunders suggested that it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over other houses in the street when people are not at home. They should call the police if they see anything suspicious. 

"We will also tell you how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This kind of help costs nothing."

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, 

I am writing to thank you for the two nights I stayed in your lovely home. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you asked for. They are nice photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. I will visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time. Thank you again. 

Love, Roy'

**The History of Farming**

Before people started farming, they searched in the forest for plants or fruits to eat. This meant they had to move around a lot to find food. About 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and over time, their villages grew larger. Some villagers could then do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers provided food for everyone. However, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it can travel thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.

**WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

Nicola Peet left school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and then joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years later, she became a manager. Here is what she said about her job:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I teach flight attendants and help them with any problems. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer, and then I talk with some of the flight attendants. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are doing. That’s my favorite part of the job, but I enjoy office work, too. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat something and then go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Text: 'Dear Maria, I'm happy to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even harder. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 

"Dear Sir, 

I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag with my name on it. Have you found this bag? 

Yours faithfully, 
Mary Johnson 

Dear Ms. Johnson, 

I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6:30 p.m. every day. 

Yours sincerely, 
J. Wilson"

Text: 'The Weather People care about the weather for many reasons, and it is important for many jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather better. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. For example, they say that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will soon rain.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the last few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who has trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing sounds than by reading. His brother wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make this game, and now it is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be sold around the world. Many schools are interested in buying it.'

**Text: 'HOW DOES THE IRISH POP GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE?**

Sleeping well is very important. When I can go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, I find it hard to sleep at night after a concert because my mind is full of music. 

Sport is also important. Before I had a car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. I can't do that now, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthy food. I also drink a lot of water because it is good for your health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I do not always drink that much. 

People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. I do not feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!

**Text: 'Bollywood'**

'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has produced over 29,000 films. This is a much higher number than in the USA, making it the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians prefer watching films to any other free-time activity, and ten million people go to the cinema every day. 

Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of every film. Indian films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make, while a Hollywood film usually costs at least $5 million. 

Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but they only act for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, who many people consider India's greatest actor, is different. He has starred in more than 140 films during his nearly 40-year acting career.

Text: 'Bill Bryson was born in the United States, but he has written many travel books about England. He lived there with his wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, they have lived in the United States. His children are now learning about life in the United States. He believes they will be happier because they have experienced two countries. Bill likes Britain and wants to return, but his daughter, Felicity, is going to start college soon, so it will be another four years before he can go back. He recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to talk about his new book. Most writers do not enjoy this; they do not like traveling around the country to sell their books. However, Bill does not mind it. He enjoys visiting new places and meeting many people. This experience is very different from his life in the United States when he is writing. In England, people drove him around in big cars, and he stayed in nice hotels. It was good because he did not have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to him, and it was fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer has only been here for a short time. The name "Giant" is fitting because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs to be cut regularly. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep. They are also used by the police because they are very intelligent. Schnauzers make great family pets. They are friendly and good with young children.

**The Ruwenzori Mountains**

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns. 

"It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food," said Mary. "It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world." 

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

Text: 

'Dear Keira, 

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I am a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework. 

Hester'

**New Books This Month**

**The Long Night**  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for many years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, where she works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take her to the nearest big city. They face many problems on the way.

**Hard Work**  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. *Hard Work* is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they do not earn much money. Then one day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop.

**Hospital or Cinema?**  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young woman from Brazil whose dream is to become a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina decide to do?

Text: 'The History of Horse Racing

Horse racing has been an important sport for a long time. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing began in the 12th century when Arab horses were brought to Europe. At first, races were long and only involved two horses, but by the early 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and included several horses competing against each other. Today, horse racing is watched by more people than any other sport in the USA, except for baseball. It is also very popular in many other parts of the world.'

Text: 'World traveler Nick Barlow loves his job. He is a British actor who travels around the world making TV shows. "People welcome me everywhere I go, and when I return home, I remember all the amazing things that happened in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still a few trips he wants to take. "I would love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he adds. On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed to make the show. Nick doesn't take many personal items, just a few shirts and pants, but he always makes sure to pack some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she enjoys listening to all his travel stories. However, sometimes there are problems. When he was in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick heard that his wife was sick in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I found out she was better."

**Text: Parrots**

You may have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups, and because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes be a problem for farmers. There are many different types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds and can easily learn to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows, where you can watch the birds do tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about many of the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend a lot of money on clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much harder to cook for fifty people than to cook for your family, but he is sure he has made the right choice.'

**Text: John Pickering**

In a small town in central England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers in a park. Last week, he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television because he is the number one singer in Japan right now. A few months ago, John visited Japan to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on his radio show. Many young people called the radio to ask the disc jockey to play his songs again. 

John, who goes by the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, will continue to work in the park in England. He is not sure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know that he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change how we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"
