**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have a new hobby: line dancing. In almost every town, there are clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs more than 200 kilos and can live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police at all. A few old men tried to protect the city streets at night, but they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was growing. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people stayed at home as much as they could.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop the thieves. They were like police officers and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown very large and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was created with 3,000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid well, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Would you like to join a camping trip this weekend? We will go to the forest in the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It gets very cold at night, so please bring warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come to Edinburgh for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are filled with music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to watch new films and plays and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

**ICE-FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch the fish that swim under the ice. 

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top," he says. "Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!"

Text: 

From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I'm not having a very good week! Yesterday, my team had a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team played much better than us. Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he has a summer job. We can't go camping together now. This morning, my sister got up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really angry with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's

One famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Here, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, made wax figures. He opened a museum for these figures in Paris, and Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was sent to prison. While in prison, she had to make copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette's. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive, and only rich people could buy them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have today. Later, when bicycles became cheaper, many people started to buy them. People began riding bicycles to work and for fun. 

Today, more people use cars than bicycles because cars are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still prefer to cycle to work. They believe there are too many cars in city centers and that it is hard to find parking!

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were excited to see the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. The trainers sometimes gave a new brush full of paint to each elephant and took the old one away. Slowly, following their trainers' instructions, the elephants painted pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the trainers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest of these animals live in special places where visitors can watch them.'

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many types of cats. They vary in size and appearance, and they behave differently. Tigers are the largest cats. They can be up to 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Most cats do not like water, but tigers often relax in water when it is hot. Lions are the only cats that live in large family groups. Several lions may work together to hunt for food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily follow other animals. All cats need good eyesight because they hunt smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I am sorry, but I cannot come to your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sad to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you again. Best wishes, Soraya'

Text: 

14 Sheffield Road  
Rotherham

Dear Mary,  

I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and tell me when you are free and where we can meet. I hope to see you then.

London

Dear Joan,  

Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don’t be late!  

Yours,  
Mary

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I am happy because last month I got a new job in the city center. I work in a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are only a few left. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, at speeds of 65 to 90 kilometres an hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson is a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding at the age of 20 and has won many competitions. We talked to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she began this sport. She said, "I have always liked sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It doesn’t take long to learn, and you can get really good in a few months." 

We also asked her if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it is so beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best for me." 

Finally, we asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It’s also important to have the right clothes so you don’t get wet, especially because you will fall down a lot at first!"'

Text: 

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,  

I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15th to 17th. I need a single room with a shower and a telephone. Please give me a quiet room on the ground floor. I will drive to the hotel. Is there a parking area? I will arrive at about 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your help.  

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed Kilimanjaro, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to the top. The Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the top succeed. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, climbers find ice and snow, and the temperature can drop below 20 degrees. Climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

**Text: Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which allows it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were few otters in Great Britain because the rivers were very dirty. Many fish and insects died, so otters could not find enough food. But today, there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.

'Dear Deshini,

I am happy that you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but I now live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you can send me? I am sending you a few photos of my family. I will send more next time I write. I hope you will write back to me soon.

Tom'

Text: 

17 Green Street  
Camden  
London  
29th August 2002  

Dear John,  

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a great teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to be a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go back to Greece. I like London a lot. We traveled to Regents Park by bus yesterday. It was very sunny, and we had a good time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write again from Greece.  

Best wishes,  
Kostas

Text: 

'Dear David, 

I will visit your country next month. I am traveling with two friends. We do not know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the center. Can you help us? 

Carlos 

Dear Carlos, 

Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she said you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! That will be okay with you, right? 

David'

**Text: Buildings**

People have always built buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We also have buildings like museums to display beautiful things. Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. 

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is lovely from every angle, not just from the top. Another famous roof is on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This interesting building looks like a tent made of glass.

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don’t have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short for me now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don’t have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. No one knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but people believe it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 metres and maybe the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in big competitions. She always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for this. 

Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, which is a long road race. She won with a very good time, the fastest of any British woman that year. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he cannot catch up.

Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Text: Piano Players - When They Were Young**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At the age of ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Later, he returned to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German, but he taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two years old, and a year later, he began playing the piano. He gave his first concert when he was six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always loved music, but he was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he would like to write his own music.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. "My ten grandchildren don’t live nearby, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad." This way, Bill has learned what young children want to read.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His fifth book is his favorite: *The Sheepdog*, which is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The film-makers used the latest technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes film-makers change books, but they didn’t change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often nicer than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards showed news events from that week, like an accident or a visit from an important person. People liked these postcards because newspapers did not have pictures at that time.

**Text: Dinosaurs**

No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago, long before there were any people on Earth. Nobody knows exactly why they all died. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5,000 different kinds. Some were very small, while others were huge. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other animals that ever lived on land. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.

**BEARS**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can harm a person. Bears are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they find food using their sense of smell. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish-brown. Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Today, not many pandas live in the wild because it is hard for them to find food.

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles live in warm areas of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat many things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they also eat larger animals or even people. There are more than ten types of crocodiles, and they all have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth but grow new ones quickly. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. They can live for a long time; the oldest crocodile in a zoo was 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Airplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. Then, in the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world and can fly at 2,500 kilometers per hour, making the trip from London to New York take only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

**The Globe Theatre**

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round, there was no roof, and people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen loved going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. The visitors ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is built in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to go home! See you at the end of September. Sue'
